Review General applications of density functional theory in photocatalysis Shiwen Du Fuxiang Zhang * State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, iChEM, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis iChEM Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Liaoning 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, iChEM, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energies by virtue of semiconductor photocatalysis has shown great significance in sustaining future energy demands, and have a deep understanding of the relationship between photocatalyst and photocatalytic activity is essential. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are becoming increasingly important for revealing the intrinsic electronic structure properties of materials and energy properties of reactions, which has been greatly developed with the development of computational methods. In this review, the applications of DFT calculations in photocatalysis are summarized and exemplified by various representative investigations in the up-to-date reports. To specify, we show how to collect, analyse and utilize the informations on photocatalysts and photocatalytic reactions with the help of the DFT calculations, such as electronic structures, surface catalytic sites, catalytic activities, possible reaction mechanisms, etc. Our discussion is intended to provide an overview on applications of the current theoretical calculations in the field of photocatalysis for a better understanding of the composition-structure-function relationships, and also to guide future experiments and computations toward the understanding and development of novel solar-energy-conversion catalysts. Graphical Abstract In this review, we summarize the general applications of density functional theory calculations in photocatalysis and discuss various case studies in up-to-date reports to illustrate their theoretical insights, which can provide vital information for different photocatalytic systems. Keywords Photocatalysis Density functional theory First-principles calculation Electronic structure Energy property 1 Introduction The growing global energy crisis is one of the major challenges in recent years owing to the increase in population and industrialization, meanwhile, the progressive consumption of traditional fossil energy has caused serious environmental concerns, such as water pollution, air pollution, and the greenhouse effect [1,2]. Thus, the pursuit of green, sustainable, and economic energy should be required urgently. Solar energy is an abundant and pollution-free energy resource, and its conversion and storage into chemical energies via artificial photosynthesis can ease the above crises [3,4]. Since the early 1970s, semiconductor-based photocatalysis has attracted widespread attention, and great efforts have been witnessed in the past few decades [5,6]. In principle, the production of solar fuels from photocatalytic reactions, including hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR), et al., can be achieved via three crucial steps: light absorption, charge transfer, and surface redox reactions [7,8]. The efficiency of solar energy conversion to fuel is proportional to the efficiency of the above main steps [9], which indicates that the relationship between these factors needs to be reasonably balanced in practical studies and appropriate strategies should be adopted to achieve high photocatalytic activity. As yet, various mixed-anion semiconductor photocatalysts have been developed to enhance the light-harvesting capacity of the widely-used oxides [10–13]. Nonetheless, the solar-to-chemical energy conversion efficiencies are still unsatisfactory due to the limited charge separation efficiency and sluggish surface reaction kinetics. To improve the charge separation efficiency, a series of tactics (e.g., heterojunction construction, facet engineering, etc.) have been implemented [14–16]. Additionally, cocatalyst loading not only can accelerate charge separation, but also provide active sites and reduce the activation energy of surface chemical reactions [17]. Although there have been tremendous efforts to develop or design new materials for photocatalysis, including visible-light-responsive semiconductors, non-noble metal cocatalysts, etc., technical hurdles remain for the development and utilization of these new photocatalytic systems. One challenging obstacle is that despite rapid advances in characterization techniques, there is a lack of in-depth understanding of the underlying principles between the intrinsic properties of semiconductors, surface active sites, and catalytic reaction mechanisms. The advancement of complex computer programs with faster computing power and material simulation methods has become an important tool for material researchers, as they can simulate the size-related properties and behaviors of nanomaterials with great confidence [18]. Therefore, the theoretical and computational studies of nanomaterials are of great significance. The Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT) electronic structure calculations, based on the time-independent Schrodinger equation, has been considered nowadays as the most predominant tool in computational materials science and solid-state physics [19,20]. The core essence of DFT is to accurately calculate the ground state energy of electrons at specific locations under finite conditions by exchanging correlation functional and approximation methods. At the same time, the ground state energy can effectively predict the physical quantities of some related properties of materials [21,22]. Therefore, DFT calculation, as a concrete bridge between theory and experiment, has great potential in exploring the reaction mechanism in the field of photocatalysis and guiding catalyst design. The specific advantages of DFT calculations in photocatalysis include the following cases: (1) predicting the electronic structure of photocatalytic materials, such as band structures, band gaps, and energy levels; (2) revealing the surface reactivities of photocatalytic materials by predicting adsorption energies, reaction pathways, and activation barriers for surface reactions; (3) providing insights into charge transfer processes at the atomic level including the movement of electrons and holes; (4) elucidating the interactions between photocatalysts and substrates; (5) predicting the formation and impact of defects in photocatalytic materials, such as vacancies, interstitials, and dopants; (6) elucidating the mechanistic details of photocatalytic reactions, including intermediate species, transition states, and reaction pathways, et al. And as expected, in recent decades, due to the rapid development of basic theories and computational methods, DFT calculations have become an important tool in photocatalysis to reveal catalytic mechanisms, evaluate catalytic performances, and provide physical/chemical insights into the origin of catalytic activities. In this review, we aim to introduce and summarize some recent applications of DFT studies in photocatalysis, and to deepen understanding of the composition-structure-function relationships of catalysts, thus shining a light on the rational design and developing new advanced photocatalytic materials towards industrial applications. First of all, we will briefly outline the theoretical software and computational methods in Section 2 with a particular focus on utilizing tactics to correct the inappropriate estimate of the electronic structural property of semiconductors based on conventional DFT approaches. Secondly, we will provide several typical investigations of the electronic and energy properties of semiconductors based on DFT calculations in Section 3, including the band structure, density of states, charge distributions, work function, formation energies, free energy of adsorption, and so on. Thirdly, we will also pay a close attention to the general utilization of semiconductor-based catalysts for a wide range of solar-driven reactions, such as HER, OER, ORR, CO2RR, NRR, and other reactions. Finally, we conclude the review and identify the opportunities and challenges for the application of DFT calculations in the research of advanced photocatalysis. 2 Software and computational methods Modern DFT calculations based on a given software package can be profitably employed to investigate various aspects of photocatalytic systems and complex photocatalytic processes. Up to now, varieties of quantum chemical software packages, such as Gaussian, Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP), ORCA, DMol3, CASTEP, ABINIT, etc. have been developed to predict the properties of various materials and reactions. Among them, VASP, a plane-wave all-electron code that use a projector-augmented wave method to describe the electron-core interactions [23], is one of the most popular packages for physics and materials science. DFT calculation plays an important role in the field of computational materials due to its high precision and low cost. However, a major difficulty in selecting density functionals for computational applications remains that achieving accurate calculations depends on the types of functionals employed to describe different electron-electron related and exchange related interactions. Many methods have been proposed to calculate the contribution of the exchange correlation to the total energy. The most commonly used of these is the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), where the exchange and correlation energies depend on the electron density and its gradient [24]. Some popular GGAs like Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [25] and Becke-Lee-Yang-Parr (BLYP) [26] correlation are the most popular semiempirical functional. These functional are successfully applied to many semiconductors including metal-containing and metal-free materials. However, it is shown that these conventional approaches are inappropriate for characterizing the semiconductors with localized electron states (d or f orbitals). This is largely due to the self-interaction error usually causing the failure to describe the strongly correlated systems [27]. One of the commonly adopted methods to overcome the failure of GGA is to use hybrid density functional that mixes exact Hartree-Fock (HF) exchange [28] with pure DFT functional, such as B3LYP [26], Heyd-Scuseria-Ernzerhof (HSE) [29,30], and PBE0 [31], etc. Take the HSE06 hybrid functional as an example [29], in which the electron-electron interaction is split into a short-range part and a long-range part, it has performed well in predicting semiconductor band gaps from their band energy differences. The other method, named GW-BSE (Bethe-Salpeter equation) [32], has also been successfully applied to dispose the approximation for the evaluation of the self-energy of a many-body system of electrons, which can provide accurate charged and neutral excitation energies, and usually been used to predict the optical spectra of various systems. Another method to ameliorate much of the error is to add the system-dependent Hubbard parameters U eff (U eff = U – J, where U and J are the coulomb potential and the exact exchange potential, respectively), namely DFT + U method [33], which includes empirical correction terms of the Hubbard Hamiltonian for localized orbitals. Although both hybrid functional and DFT + U methods show improved performances for the electronic properties, the values of the percentage of HF exchange and U eff are usually determined by comparing the calculated parameters and the band gap determined from the experimental data, meaning different semiconductors require different HF exchange percentages or U eff parameters. It should also be noted that the computational cost for the hybrid density functional methods (such as HSE06, etc.) and GW-BSE method increases significantly with respect to the DFT + U formalism due to the evaluation of nonlocal exchange integrals, especially for large systems or complex materials. As mentioned above, the accuracy of the DFT method depends hugely on the functional used. With the development of density functional, the current DFT implemented in many codes is becoming more reliable and robust. This renders the structural properties, electronic properties and energy properties of semiconductors to be systematically investigated for possible prediction of photocatalytic performances and rational design towards highly efficient catalysts. 3 Theoretical analysis of photocatalysts 3.1 Band structure The electronic band gap of a semiconductor determines its ultimate efficiency in exploiting natural sunlight in photocatalytic applications. The positions of the top of the valence band (VB) and the bottom of the conduction band (CB) in a semiconduction material determine its redox ability, owing to these ones are the electronic levels involved in charge transfer from or to the catalyst, respectively. During DFT calculations, the band gap value (E g) of a given semiconductor is defined as the difference between the eigenvalues of the CB minimum (CBM) and the VB maximum (VBM). Yu et al. [34] investigated the crystal structures and band structures of anatase, rutile, and brookite TiO2 by first-principles calculations. Fig. 1 shows that the calculated E g of the three titania are 1.86–2.38 eV, all much smaller than the experimental values (3.0–3.3 eV). This originates from the fact that the conventional GGA functional usually underestimates the E g of semiconductors owing to the existence of a derivative discontinuity of the energy with respect to the number of electrons [35,36]. Meanwhile, the calculated band structures show that the CBM and VBM of anatase titania lie in point G and point B in the Brillouin zone (Fig. 1(a)), respectively, while that of rutile or brookite titania lie in point G (Figs. 1(b) and (c)). These results indicate that anatase titania is an indirect band gap semiconductor, while rutile and brookite are the ones with direct band gap. Generally, a semiconductor with an indirect band gap always exhibits a longer lifetime of photoexcited charge carriers than one with a direct band gap. This is because photogenerated electrons cannot jump directly from CB to VB in a semiconductor because they are widely separated in k space, meaning the diffusion length and reaction time of the charge carriers excited in the indirect semiconductor will be increased. From the point of charge carriers’ lifetime, indirect band gaps may be conducive to improving the catalytic activity of the photocatalyst [37,38]. However, essentially, indirect band gaps give low absorption coefficients with respect to the direct ones [39], which in turn may not be conducive to improving the photocatalytic activity. Therefore, it is important to consider the absorption coefficient and carrier lifetime simultaneously to determine the efficiency of the photocatalysts and their designs. A detailed discussion about the absorption coefficient will be presented in Section 3.3. It has been known that including some exact HF exchange in the modern hybrid density functional (e.g., B3LYP, PBE0, HSE, B3PW91, etc.) could lead to substantially ameliorating the shortcoming to obtain improved band gaps. For instance, Umezawa and coworkers investigated the band structure of rutile TiO2 by means of a first-principles approach described the exchange correlation with HSE hybrid functional (using 20% HF exchange), and a gap of 3.05 eV was calculated, very close to the experimental observed one (3.0 eV) [42]. Goddard et al. [40] showed that the B3PW91 hybrid functional can provide accurate E g predictions for CuInSe2 with a mean average deviation of only 0.03 eV with respect to the experimental result (Fig. 1(d)), further proving the superiority of hybrid functional in investigating the band structures of semiconductors. In addition to studying the band structure of materials with known band gaps, hybrid functional methods can also be used to predict novel photocatalytic materials. Considering that the location of the band edge is one of the most important criteria in the photocatalysis process, the CBE (conduction band edge) and VBE (valence band edge) must lie above the H+/H2 reduction level and below the O2/H2O oxidation level, respectively. By means of DFT, the relative positions of band edges can be calculated as follows [43]: (1) E CBE = X – 0.5E gap – 4.5eV (2) E VBE = E CBE + E gap where X and 4.5 eV are the geometric mean of the electronegativities of the constituent atoms and the free energy of the electron relative to the vacuum energy level, respectively. For instance, Xu et al. [41] identified a new class of compelling 2D materials β-MX (M = Ge or Sn, X = S or Se) with more accurate E g based on hybrid functional calculations. As exhibited in Figs. 1(e)–(h), the calculated results show that the shapes of bands calculated using the PBE and HSE06 are nearly identical and the E HSE g is nearly 1–1.2 eV larger than that calculated at the PBE level. Moreover, the appropriate band structures (E HSE g = 2.55–2.99 eV, Fig. 1(i)) qualify the monolayer β-MX family and can be utilized as promising photocatalysts. Contrastingly, the HSE06 method and GW-BSE method offer improved accuracy in predicting electronic structures and band gaps of materials compared to standard DFT functionals. However, their computational cost and complexity can be limiting factors for their applicability, especially for the GW-BSE method. Band structure modification (or band gap engineering) is an important aspect for semiconductors in the field of photocatalysis. One way is to dope foreign elements into the lattice of the host materials with a wide band gap, which usually includes two doping modes, namely n-type doping and p-type doping. The introduction of a trace amount of impurities into semiconductors can form impurity levels in the band gap of the host materials, resulting in a positive visible light response. For instance, Hyeon et al. [44] found that the introduction of a Cu atom in a Ti vacancy can produce new mid-gap states with Cu d x2–y2 and d z2 character between the valence and conduction bands of TiO2 (Figs. 2(a) and (b) ). Fig. 2(c) shows that the states closer to the VB edge are associated with Cu d z2 and O p (on neighboring O atoms) states, while the ones closer to the CB are composed of Cu d x2–y2 and O p states. These formed donor energy levels can reduce electron transition energy to the CB, thereby increasing visible-light harvesting of TiO2. However, these d states in the mid-band gap usually exhibit strong localization of the photogenerated electrons and decrease their mobility, thus leading to reduced photocatalytic performances [45,46]. Nonmetal elements doping, especially for nitrogen (N) doping, has been widely used to broaden the absorption range of metal oxides, and the origin of the visible light absorption of N-doped ones can be well understood with the aid of first-principles calculations. For example, Liu and coworkers [47] calculated the electronic structures of BaLa4Ti4O15–x N y with different N/O substitution sites by means of the standard DFT code and found there were two dominant changes occurred with N doping at the three different oxygen sites of O1, O2, and O3 (Figs. 2(d)–(g)). Calculated results show that the N substitution of the O site is indeed the hole-type dopant to make the downward shift of the E F, meanwhile, different E g values can be obtained with the N doping by substituting the different lattice O sites. Although the gap values are slightly different, the reduced E g can facilitate the harvest of visible-light of the BaLa4Ti4O15 photocatalyst. The introduction of defects is another effective way to modify band structures, which also can be shed light based on DFT calculations. In a recent study, Xue et al. [48] found that the incorporation of oxygen vacancies (VO) into the anatase TiO2 lattice can create a new band level located between the CBM and VBM but close the CBM (Figs. 2(h) and (i)), which can accept light-excited carriers from VB, thereby reducing the total energy of carrier transitions. Wu et al. [49] calculated the band structures of BiOI with/without iodine- (I-) vacancies using the standard DFT method. Fig. 2(j) shows that the E g of BiOI will be decreased accompanied with the VBM and CBM generally moved down when 6.25% and 50% I-vacancies are introduced. In this case, the E F moved up to the CB and a positive VBM position can be obtained, resulting in enhanced photocatalytic oxidative activities. Besides the predicting of band gaps, DFT calculations also play a crucial role in determining the band edge positions in a material for understanding its electronic structure, carrier transport properties, optical behavior, and chemical reactivity [50]. For example, the position of the band edges influences the carrier transport properties of a material, investigations of the location of the CB edge relative to the Fermi level can determine whether a material behaves as a conductor, semiconductor, or insulator. For chemical reactivity, the position of the HOMO can affect the material’s ability to donate electrons in chemical reactions, while the LUMO position can determine its electron-accepting properties. Additionally, by controlling the band edge positions, researchers can tailor the material’s properties for specific applications in photocatalysis. 3.2 Density of states (DOS) The DOS is essentially the number of different states that electrons are allowed to occupy at a particular energy level, i.e. the number of electronic states per unit volume and per unit energy [51]. In fact, DOS and band structures correspond essentially to each other. The difference is that calculations of the DOS allow one to investigate the general distribution of states as a function of energy and also to determine the gap between energy bands of a material, as well as allow an in-depth understanding of the orbital interactions. For instance, Qiao et al. [52] studied the effect of O-terminated Ti3C2 acting as a cocatalyst in promoting H2 production by the DOS analysis. As shown in Fig. 3(a) , there are continuous electronic states crossing the E F of O-terminated Ti3C2, indicating its excellent electrical conductivities and exceptional capability to transport electrons. The validity of the proposed theoretical results was verified by the subsequent photocatalytic H2 production experiment. It is worth noting that a popular use of DOS is to determine the composition of the band structure, especially the CB and VB of a photocatalyst. Figs. 3(b) and (c) show the calculated DOS of β-TaON and γ-TaON, in which the Ta 5d states contribute mainly to the CBM, while the O 2p and N 2p states contribute to the VBM [53]. Moreover, better hybridization between O 2p and N 2p states occurs at the VBM in γ-TaON than that in β-TaON, resulting in an enlarged band gap of γ-TaON. Hence, it is reasonable to consider that the electronic structure of γ-TaON contributes to its better photocatalytic performance, which is consistent with the experimental observations [54,55]. Besides pure semiconductors, the DOS calculations also play important roles in discussing the effects of heteroatoms doped into the photocatalysts. Zhou et al. [56] showed that the doping of transition metal (Mn, Fe, Co) ions would introduce new energy levels in the VB edge position or even the intermediate gap of perovskite SrTiO3, resulting in electron excitation from the doping level to CB, which is the reason for the observed absorption edge redshift. In addition to metal doping, nonmetal doping also has obvious effects on the electronic structures of the parent material. Yu et al. [57] monitored the effects of phosphorus (P) doping on the g-C3N4 by the DFT calculations. Calculated DOS shown in Figs. 3(d) and (e) reveal that the intrinsic E g of g-C3N4 shrinks from 2.68 to 2.34 eV when the P atom replaces the corner region and bay area C atom in the carbon nitride skeleton. Meanwhile, the midgap states arising from the hybridization of C 2s2p, N 2s2p and P 3s3p appear below the CB of pristine g-C3N4, which can further reduce its E g to 1.97eV. As a result, the midgap states can accommodate the electrons photoexcited from VB of P-doped g-C3N4 (PCN-D), resulting in superior photocatalytic efficiency with respect to undoped g-C3N4. Zhang et al. [58] confirmed that the incorporation of N atoms into the lattice of Sr5Nb4O15 can raise its VBM position due to the strong hybridization with the O 2p and N 2p orbitals, which endows the visible-light-responsive characteristics of Sr5Nb4O15–x N x (Fig. 3(f)). This up-shift of VB position is due to the substitution of O element with less electronegative and more polarizable N element, which is a common phenomenon for the N-doped metal oxides and oxynitride photocatalysts [59]. Although the E g from DFT calculations with conventional functional are generally underestimated, they nonetheless often provide important insight into the physicochemical behavior of the materials, such as heterojunctions, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), etc. Walsh and coworkers [60] investigated the electronic structure of MIL-125 and found that the VB is composed of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) aromatic 2p orbitals, while the CB is composed of O 2p orbitals and Ti 3d orbitals (Figs. 3(g) and (h)). The phenomenon of complete separation of CB and VB means that the position of VB can be changed via bdc linker modification (e.g., bdc-NH2 for MIL-125-NH2) without affecting the CB, demonstrating the high adjustability of the band structure of MOF materials. Lin et al. [61] proposed a novel approach to fabricate a Z-scheme photocatalytic system using DFT calculations with the HSE06 hybrid functional. According to the PDOS results presented in the left image of Fig. 3(i), it was found that MoSe2 has a lower CBM compared to g-C3N4. In contrast, its VBM is higher than g-C3N4 in this heterojunction structure. This indicates that g-C3N4/MoSe2 forms a typical type-I heterojunction. After the introduction of boron (B), as shown in the right image of Fig. 3(i), the VBM of B-doped g-C3N4 in this hybrid structure becomes higher than that of MoSe2. However, the CBM of MoSe2 remains lower than that of B-doped g-C3N4. This shows that B can function as a band alignment modulator and the newly formed heterojunction could change to a type-II or Z-scheme band structure. These results not only provide a new way to understand the band alignment transition of heterojunctions by elemental doping but also present a facile method for the rational design of efficient heterojunction-based photocatalysis systems. 3.3 Optical property High efficiency photocatalysts require a large light absorption coefficient to produce high density photoexcited electron-hole pairs. The light absorption performance of semiconductor photocatalyst is related to its electronic structure, and the absorption coefficient I(ω) can be obtained by the following equation (Eq. (3)) [62]: (3) I ( ω ) = 2 ω [ ε 1 2 ( ω ) + ε 2 2 ( ω ) - ε 1 ( ω ) ] 1 2 where ε 1(ω) and ε 2(ω) are the real part and imaginary part of the frequency-dependent complex dielectric constant ε(ω), respectively. Xu et al. [63] calculated the optical absorption spectra of C2N, MoSi2N4, and the C2N/MoSi2N4 heterojunction by the HSE06 method. As shown in Fig. 4(a) , pure MoSi2N4 monolayer shows relatively weak visible light absorption efficiency, while pure C2N monolayer exhibits obviously better absorption efficiency, especially in the high energy region of visible light. The band gaps estimated from the optical spectra for MoSi2N4 and C2N are approximately 2.05 eV, slightly larger than the experimental observation (1.94 and 1.96 eV) [64,65]. These discrepancies usually arise due to various factors such as the involving approximations in the exchange-correlation functional used to describe electron-electron interactions, unfully account for quasiparticle effects (e.g., electron self-energy corrections), etc. Fortunately, after being coupled with C2N, the C2N/MoSi2N4 heterojunction also displays a good visible light absorption capacity, significantly better than pure C2N and MoSi2N4 monolayer, which is very helpful for capturing sunlight to excite charge carriers. Another important information that can be obtained from the calculated absorption spectra is the optical absorption coefficient, which is a semi-quantitative characteristic of absorption capacity for photocatalysts. For example, Lee et al. [66] used the GW-BSE method to evaluate the solar energy absorption capacity of the GeC/GaN vdW heterojunction. Fig. 4(b) shows the relationship between the light absorption coefficient (α) and the photon energy (ω) of GaN monolayer, GeC monolayer and GeC/GaN vdW heterostructure. It can be seen that the absorption edge of the GeC/GaN vdW heterostructure is located in the visible region, and has a redshift relative to the absorption edge of the GaN monolayer and the GeC monolayer, showing a wider light absorption range in the visible region, with an absorption coefficient of about 105 cm−1. This indicates that the GeC/GaN vdW heterostructure has strong light response and light absorption ability. It is worth mentioning that the calculations of the absorption spectrum of a photocatalyst require strict consideration of the E g of the model catalyst, so it is necessary to use hybrid functional to execute the calculations. However, considering that the DFT calculations based on hybrid functional have high computational costs, the calculations of the absorption spectrum are not extensive. 3.4 Bader charge The studies of atomic charge can reveal the bonding environment and charge distribution of active sites, which are of great significance to understand the mechanisms of catalytic reactions. Currently, the popular charge distribution analyses, including Mulliken charge [67], Hirshfeld charge [68], Bader charge [69], Natural charge [70], Voronoi Deformation Density charge [71], etc., all are implemented by different algorithms that assign electron charge to atoms. Among them, the Bader charge has been widely employed to analyze the charge population and charge transfer for blank (e.g., the ones that involve the doping of heteroatoms, the presence of defect, heterojunctions, etc.) and species-adsorbed photocatalysts. For instance, Liu et al. [72] analyzed the Bader charge distribution of original In2O3 and N-doped In2O3 to understand the promotion effect of N doping on CO2 adsorption on In2O3 photocatalyst. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , the N-doped Bader charge difference between the associated Lewis acids (In3+) and Lewis bases (O2– or N3–) increases substantially, which means that N-doped In2O3 forms more active surface-beaten Lewis pairs (SFLPs) relative to pure In2O3. The unsaturated indium (In) and adjacent O may form SFLP sites, which are more likely to adsorb and activate CO2. Wang and coworkers [73] employed Bader charge analysis to investigate the electron distribution of ZnIn2S4 after the Zn vacancies (VZn) were fabricated. Figs. 5(b) and (c) show that the introduction of VZn exacerbated the changes in the original electron cloud of S atoms, that is the S atoms originated from the VZn are in an unsaturated coordination state accompanied by fewer electrons (0.56–0.73 e) when compared to that in the perfect ZnIn2S4 (0.82–0.84 e). These unsaturated coordinated S could act as the reactive sites, which is favorable to the adsorption of CO2 and to initiate the effective C=O bond break. Peter’s group found that two different Bi-sites (Bi1 and Bi2, Fig. 5(d)) in Bi2S3 have similar Bader charges of 1.13 and 1.14, whereas the three different Bi sites (Bi1, Bi2, and Bi3) on the surface of Bi19S27Cl3 have Bader charges of 1.18, 1.14, and 0.99, respectively [74]. This charge difference could lead to the formation of charge-polarized Bi sites and thus inducing an intrinsic electric field to render better separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Owing to the different E F in the different catalysts, there is obvious charge redistribution at the interface of heterojunction. Qu et al. [75] found that the Bader charge of Fe atoms in the surface of Bi2Fe4O9 is much higher than that of Fe atoms in BiFeO3 after they are contacted (Fig. 5(e)). This means Fe atoms on the surface of Bi2Fe4O9 are slightly ionic to lose electrons, indicating the presence of Fe−O channel for rapid charge transfer at the interface of BiFeO3/Bi2Fe4O9 heterojunction. To investigate the variation in charge density, Fang et al. [76] used Bader charge to analyze the charge densities of the Cu2Se/CdSSe heterostructure. The calculated result reveals that the charge redistribution mainly occurs near the interface between the Cu2Se portion and the CdSSe, with a part of the electron (0.16 e−/unit model) transfer from the Cu2Se to the CdSSe semiconductor (Fig. 5(f)). The transfer of electrons causes the band of the CdSSe semiconductor to bend downward, forming Ohmic contact between Cu2Se and CdSSe, which is favorable for the separation of photogenerated charges during the photocatalytic reaction. Conversely, Bader charge calculations on CoSe/CdSSe show that electrons can be transferred from the CdSSe side across the interface to the CoSe side in a model of 0.5145 e−/unit, causing the CB of CdSSe to bend upward to form the Schottky barrier [77]. These differences are determined by the intrinsic properties of the cocatalyst, and allow them to facilitate the separation of photogenic charges in different ways. The effective adsorption between adsorbed species and catalyst is one of the key steps in the reaction. The calculation of Bader charge to study the charge redistribution between adsorbed species and catalyst is an important way to understand the catalytic performance of catalysts. Yu et al. [78] studied the charge transfer during the formation of the EDTA-O2 complex on the basis of Bader charge analysis, and the results showed that the charge distribution of the O atom near the EDTA increased from 6 to 6.08 e− and that of the other O atom increased from 6.02 e− (Fig. 5(g)). The charge transfer of EDTA to O2 was confirmed [78]. These results show the interaction between EDTA and O2 clearly, which favors the activation of O2 because O=O is more easily destroyed when attacked by e− produced by the photocatalyst. Fig. 5(h) shows a net charge transfer of 0.42 e− from the defective BiOCl (001) surface to the adsorbed H2O, which is much more than that from the defect-free BiOCl (001) surface (0.08 e−), making the adsorbed H2O negatively charged for water activation [79]. In the photocatalytic N2 reduction reactions, the more electrons of one intermediate obtain means the higher degree of activation in the target bonds [81]. To determine the reaction pathway of N2 photoreduction, Yang et al. [80] tracked the Bader charge of N-containing adsorbents along alternating and remote paths. As shown in Fig. 5(i), the Bader charges of the first two hydrogenation steps increase by similar electrons on alternating (0.21 and 0.52 |e|) and distant (0.21 and 0.69 |e|) paths. The Bader charge of *NHNH2 (alternate reaction pathway) is 0.55 |e| higher than that of the distant pathway of *N (0.32 |e|), and the N-containing substances in the alternate reaction pathway obtain more electrons from the iron active site than those in the distant pathway. These results demonstrate that the photocatalytic N2 reduction over FeCo2O4 tends to follow the alternating reaction pathway, consistenting with the experimental observations. 3.5 Charge density difference (CDD) The CDD (Δρ) is a non-quantitative descriptor of the charge transfer between two species (e.g., photocatalyst I and photocatalyst II in heterojunction, photocatalyst and adsorbate, etc.) via bonding interactions in a catalytic system, which can be defined as follows [82]: (4) Δρ = ρ H – ρ pI – ρ pII where ρ H, ρ pI and ρ pII are the charge density of the hybrid system, the isolated photocatalyst I and the isolated photocatalyst II in the hybrid system, respectively. Zhang et al. [83] reported Cu δ+-modified (δ < 2) defective zinc-aluminium layered double hydroxide (ZnAl-LDH) nanosheets can serve as an N2 reduction reaction (NRR) catalyst with an enhanced NRR activity. Calculations in Fig. 6(a) show that there is a significant CDD between the Cu center (electron depletion region, blue) and the surrounding VO (electron accumulation region, yellow), which means that the coordination unsaturated Cu atoms carry less positive charge, reducing some of the Cu2+ to low-price Cu δ+. In the presence of VO and nearby electron-rich Cu δ+, N2 can be easily adsorbed on the surface of ZnAl-LDH nanosheets where the transfer of electrons to the N2 molecule can readily occur to obtain an enhanced NRR activity. Li et al. [84] prepared a Z-type heterostructure consisting of sulfur-rich vacancy ZnIn2S4 (Sv-ZnIn2S4) and MoSe2 for efficient photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. Fig. 6(b) shows the CDD side view of Sv-ZnIn2S4/MoSe2, where the red and blue sides represent the accumulation and consumption of electron density, respectively. It is observed that the electron cloud density shows an obvious local distribution between the Mo atom in MoSe2 and the unsaturated coordination S atom in Sv-ZnIn2S4, which intuitively reflects the strong bonding effect between Mo and S. In addition, it can be seen that the surface of MoSe2 is dominated by red, while that of Sv-ZnIn2S4 is dominated by blue, indicating that electrons in Sv-ZnIn2S4 are transferred to MoSe2 along the intimate boundary. The internal electric field is then generated in the Sv-ZnIn2S4/MoSe2 heterostructure. Mao et al. [85] utilized single-atom copper (Cu) as electron bridges (SAEB) at the contact interface between Cu1/MoS2 and MIL-125-NH2 to realize a highly active and stable CO2 photoreduction catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6(c) (above image), the N−Cu1−S bridge is surrounded by the electron depletion region and the accumulation region, indicating that N−Cu1−S can act as a SAEB to implement the Z-scheme charge transfer mode. In addition, when an additional electron is introduced under light irradiation as the simulated photogenerated electron, the simulated “photogenerated electron” tends to be distributed around the Ti−O cluster in Cu-SAEB, as shown in Fig. 6(c). These phenomena suggest that Ti−O clusters act as electron traps during light irradiation and can be further used as active sites for CO2 reduction. Although it is generally recognized that the one-way charge transfer from one species to another is dependent on their relative electron accepting and donating abilities [86], the two-way charge transfer can also be observed under certain circumstances. For example, it is found that the charge transfer of N2 molecule and boron (B) atom in NRR system is bidirectional, and there are charge accumulation and depletion phenomena over B decorated g-C3N4 (B/g-C3N4) photocatalysts [86]. As exhibited in Fig. 6(d), while accepting the lone pair of electrons, the B atom provides electrons to the antibonding orbital of N2, which plays a key role in the capture and activation of N2. Apart from the three-dimensional CDD, planar-averaged electron density difference is also usually employed to exhibit the charge transfer in the catalytic system. For instance, Zhang et al. [87] studied the interfacial charge transfer path of CeO2/polymer C3N4 (PCN) heterojunction by calculating the planar mean electron density difference. The planar mean electron density difference Δρ in Fig. 6(e) shows that the PCN part near the interface is positively charged, while the CeO2 part near the interface is negatively charged due to electron migration. This indicates that CeO2 combined with PCN can effectively construct heterojunction. Huang et al. [88] studied the interaction between g-C3N4 and RGO sheets using hybrid DFT and demonstrated that O atoms play a crucial role in RGO matrix composites. CDD calculation results (Fig. 6(d)) show that the change of charge density at the interface of g-C3N4/RGO composites is significantly greater than that at the interface of g-C3N4/GR composites. With the increase of O atom concentration, the transfer charge at the interface becomes more and more obvious, indicating that the interaction intensity between g-C3N4 and RGO sheet becomes more and more complex. In addition, strong charge depletion was found on the lower side of g-C3N4 (as opposed to the interface), forming a hole-rich region, while charge accumulation occurred on the O atom along the C–O bond direction, forming an electron-rich site. This indicates that the interaction leads to the negative charge of the O atom in RGO, which is the active site and is conducive to improving the photocatalytic performance of g-C3N4/RGO composites. 3.6 Electron localization function (ELF) The ELF is an important tool for identifying regions where electrons are localized in atomic and molecular systems [92]. Generally, ELF values are in the range of 0 to 1 and are represented by different electronic positioning. The regions close to 1 indicate the presence of strong covalent electrons or lone pair electrons, while regions close to 0.5 indicate homogeneous electron gas or the presence of metallic bonds, and regions close to 0 indicate regions of low electron density [92]. Li et al. [89] investigated the effects of the halogen doping strategy on improving the photocatalytic ozonation activity of g-C3N4. ELF results depicted in Fig. 6(g) show that g-C3N4 (CN) has a highly conjugated structure and a highly symmetrical electron distribution. The doping of halogen has different effects on the electron distribution of CN: the electrons of Br and I migrate to CN due to the decrease of electronegativity, forming an electron-poor region; Electron migration in Cl–CN is not as obvious as Br and I, and its electron distribution is not highly polarized. For F–CN, F on F–CN can hold onto surrounding electrons, forming an electron-rich region centered on the C–F bond. The results show that doped halogen causes uneven electron distribution, forming a water-thin point on CN, narrowing Eg of CN, and increasing e– migration space. In particular, F doping can enhance the mass transfer of O3/O2 and inhibit the recombination of e–/h+. Huang et al. [90] prepared a novel NiSeS cocatalyst with Ni-Se double vacancy (VNi/VSe) and constructed NiSeS/ZnSe heterojunction for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. The DFT calculation in Fig. 6(h) shows that the ELF value of NiSeS/ZnSe with VNi/VSe added is smaller than that of NiSeS/ZnSe without VNi/VSe added, indicating that the electron distribution around VSe is highly delocalized, which is conducive to the inflow and outflow of electrons. As a result, electrons around VSe are easily captured by Ni sites around VSe for use in photocatalytic hydrogen production [93]. Zhang et al. [91] employed Sr2Bi2Nb2TiO12 nanosheets with VO as photocatalysts for CO2 reduction. ELF results (Fig. 6(i)) illustrate that there exists more covalent interaction between CO2 and atoms around VO for Sr2Bi2Nb2TiO12 with respect to Sr2Bi2Nb2TiO12, stating the presence of VO can efficiently adsorb and activate CO2 in the photoreduction process. 3.7 Work function (WF) The work function (W F, which is also abbreviated as Ф) of a catalyst (e.g., metal, semiconductor, etc.) can be defined as the minimum energy required to extract one electron from this catalyst, which is one of the fundamental electronic properties of bare or coated catalyst surfaces. The energy difference between the vacuum and Fermi levels can be estimated based on the electrostatic potential, using the equation (Eq. (5)) as follows: (5) W F = E V – E F where the E V and E F represent the electrostatic potentials of the vacuum and Fermi energy levels of the semiconductor, respectively. With the aid of W F calculations, the electronic properties of the catalyst surface can be clearly understood. For instance, Chen et al. [94] studied the effect of metal Fe-doping on the photocatalytic nitrogen fixation activity, and found that Fe-doping reduced the surface W F of Bi2MoO6 observably. The reduced surface function would boost the charge transport from bulk to surface, thus resulting in an enhanced photocatalytic nitrogen fixation activity. A similar phenomenon of reduced W F for improving the transport and separation efficiency of the photogenerated carriers can also be observed in the systems such as doping CdS with nonmetal selenium (Se) [95], introduction oxygen vacancy in In2O3 [96], etc. Coupling two semiconductors together to construct a heterojunction is one of the most efficient ways to achieve electron-hole pair separation. Systematic investigations of the W F of each component in heterojunction are of great importance for understanding the transfer behavior and mechanism of photo-excited carriers during photocatalytic reactions. In this case, the interface dipole will be formed if the W F of the two materials forming the heterojunction are different. The directions of the dipole would be toward the layer with a smaller W F [97], which is also important for accelerating the separation and migration of charge carriers. Additionally, the results show that the heterojunction properties, carrier transfer behavior and photocatalytic mechanism of the materials are highly dependent on the semiconductor properties (n-type or p-type) and W F (or E F) of the materials. For example, He et al. [98] proposed new type-II vdW GaSe/CN and Ga2SSe/CN heterostructures through first-principles calculations. The WF of single-layer g-CN, GaSe and Ga2SSe, and GaSe/CN and Ga2SSe/CN heterostructures is shown in Fig. 7(a) . It can be seen from the figure that the W F after the formation of heterostructures is lower than that of single-layer g-CN, and single-layer g-CN is more likely to lose electrons. Xian et al. [99] synthesized a Z-scheme heterojunction Co3O4/TiO2 photocatalyst for photocatalytic degradation of enrofloxacin, and proposed a Z-scheme mechanism based on W F calculation. Figs. 7(b) and (c) shows the W F values of TiO2 and Co3O4, calculated as 4.84 eV (Ф T) and 5.69 eV (Ф C), respectively. Due to the difference of W F (Ф T < Ф C), electrons at the contact interface will flow from TiO2 to Co3O4, thus forming an internal electric field at the contact interface, which is conducive to electron transfer at the heterojunction interface and improves the photodegradation efficiency. Yu et al. [100] explored TiO2/CsPbBr3 photocatalyst to promote CO2 photoreduction into solar fuel. As shown in Figs. 7(d) and (e), the W F of rutile type TiO2 (110) and CsPbBr3 quantum dots (001) are 7.08 and 5.79 eV, respectively. When they touch each other, electrons will flow from CsPbBr3 to rutile TiO2, creating an internal electric field at the TiO2/CsPbBr3 interface. Through the comprehensive analysis of the calculated E F and other experimental results, it is proposed that the S-scheme charge transfer route is formed at the TiO2/CsPbBr3 interface under light irradiation, which greatly promotes the separation of electron-hole pairs and promotes the efficient photoreduction of CO2. However, there are many similarities in the mechanism of Z-scheme and S-scheme heterojunctions, which easily lead to confusion in determining the true features. Therefore, it is necessary to combine W F calculations with other experimental results to infer the real reaction mechanisms. Besides the heterojunctions constructed by coupling two different semiconductors, W F calculations also play key roles in investigating the electron-hole pairs’ separation in heterophase homojunctions or facet heterojunctions. For instance, Cui et al. [101] calculated the theoretical W F of hydrogenated rutile TiO2 (H-rutile-TiO2) (110) and anatase-TiO2 (112) to be 3.37 and 4.45 eV, respectively. This means that H-rutile-TiO2 has a higher E F than anatase-TiO2, thus resulting in the transfer of photogenerated electrons from H-rutile-TiO2 to anatase-TiO2 under UV-vis light irradiation. Xiong and colleagues [102] studied the accumulation of photoexcited electrons and holes on different Cu2O surfaces. Figs. 7(f) and (g) shows that the W F (ca. 7.2 eV) of Cu2O (100) is much higher than that of Cu2O (111) (ca. 4.8 eV), indicating that electrons and holes are more inclined to transfer from their bulk phase to the (100) and (111) surfaces (as shown in Fig. 7(f)). This charge-space separation has been confirmed by photocurrent measurements and selective photodeposition of Pd cocatalysts. Calculations of W F have also been carried out to understand the anisotropic deposition of cocatalysts over other catalysts, e.g., SrTiO3:Al [103], BiOCl [104], etc. For the heterojunctions composed of semiconductor and metal/semimetal, there exist two models, namely Schottky junction and Ohmic contact. W F calculations are commonly used as a critical parameter and an intrinsic reference for electron-transfer potential in these hybrid structures. As exhibited in Fig. 8 , for n-type semiconductors, when the W F of metal/semimetal (W m) is larger than that of the n-type semiconductor (W s) and come into contact with each other, an equilibrium state between the E F of metal/semimetal (E fm) and n-type semiconductor (E fs) will be built up. In this case, the electrons will diffuse from the n-type semiconductor to the metal/semimetal, which would lead to an upward bending of the energy band of the semiconductor to metal/semimetal, and consequently forming Schottky junction with a barrier (φ SB, the left side of Fig. 8(a)) [108,109]. In the other case, the n-type semiconductor has a larger W F than metal/semimetal (W s > W m), the downward bending of the energy band of the semiconductor to metal/semimetal will be formed to cause an Ohmic contact without barrier (the left side of Fig. 8(b)) [110]. For the p-type semiconductor (in the right side of Fig. 8), when Schottky junctions or Ohmic contacts are formed, the relationship between the W s and the W m will be the opposite with respect to that for the n-type-based junctions. 3.8 Potential drop (ΔV) and electrostatic potential difference (EPD) Construction of heterojunction using materials with different W F is one efficient way to enhance separation and migration. As discussed before, the charge redistribution would be presented near the heterojunction interface due to the W F differences. This phenomenon can be further verified by calculating the planar averaged electrostatic potential along the z direction [111]. It provides a smoothed representation of the local potential profile, enabling a macroscopic view of the electric field distribution and charge distribution across the interface. The potential drop (ΔV), also known as the voltage drop, represents the change in electric potential or energy levels near the interface of the heterostructure, which can be calculated by subtracting the electrostatic potentials at two specific points or regions in the heterostructure. It quantifies the difference in potential energy experienced by charge carriers as they move across the interface. For instance, Tang et al. [105] studied the van der Waals heterostructure formed by PtS2 and arsenene (Are) monolayers based on first-principles calculations. The calculated potential profile across the interface shown in Fig. 7(h) reveals that the ΔV between PtS2 and Are layers are found to be approximately 4.23 eV, which renders electrons to be driven from Are to PtS2, leading to enrichment of holes and electrons in Are and PtS2, respectively. As a consequence, a significant built-in electric field could be formed, which can promote carrier transfer to reduce the recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Similar phenomena about the formed ΔV across the interface have been also observed in blue-P/BSe inter-layer heterostructure [82], MoS2/BiOX (X = Cl, Br, I) [112], and MSSe/GaN (M = Mo, W) van der Waals heterostructures [113], etc. Another key factor in the separation of photogenerated charge carriers is the electrostatic potential difference (EPD), which is usually associated with the build-in electric field between the top and bottom surfaces [114], and is also suitable for the photocatalyst in the presence of heterojunctions. Kou et al. [106] investigated the potential of a two-dimensional Janus WSSe monolayer as an excellent photocatalyst for overall water splitting. Fig. 7(i) shows that the EPD produced by the intrinsic dipole between two chalcogen layers is 0.73 eV for the WSSe monolayer. In addition, electrons (holes) are pushed into the Se (S) layer by the built-in polarization field, resulting in a lower binding energy of excitons, which is conducive to promoting the separation of photoexcited electrons and holes and improving the photocatalytic efficiency. Wang et al. [107] found that there is an observable in-plane averaged EPD of 1.44 eV is obtained at the interface region of the C3N/C3B heterostructure, as exhibited in Fig. 7(j). Combined with the thickness of the heterojunction, it is estimated that the built-in electric field of the C3N/C3B layer is ~0.4 V Å−1, which is conducive to the photogenerated electrons of the C3B layer and the photogenerated holes of the C3N layer, and further leads to the formation of Z-scheme carrier transfer pathway of the C3N/C3B heterostructure during the photocatalytic reaction. Both potential drop and electrostatic potential differences exhibit similarities with band offset in that they are all related to energy levels and electric potential at the interface of semiconductor heterostructures. The former two usually indicate the change in electric potential between two points or regions at the interface, whereas band offset signifies the energy difference between the valence or conduction bands of two semiconductors in a heterostructure. For the band offset, there are three methods that can be used to obtain the target results accurately: the method based on core-level reference, the method based on averaged electrostatic potential, and the method based on vacuum level. The first method uses the energy levels of core-level atomic orbitals as a reference point to determine the band alignment at the interface, while the second one uses the spatially averaged electrostatic potential along the interface plane to infer the band offset between the two materials. The last method references the energy levels to the vacuum level as a universal standard to determine the band offset at the interface. The detailed discussions can refer to the review provided by Zhang et al. [115]. 3.9 Effective masses The diffusion and separation rates of the carriers produced by the photoexcitation are key to determining the quantum efficiency of the photocatalytic reaction, because these light-generated electrons and holes need to diffuse to the active site on the surface of the photocatalyst before the photocatalytic reaction can be carried out. The carrier transfer rate (v) can be evaluated indirectly by the effective mass of the electrons and holes, which can be explained by the following equation (Eq. (6)): (6) v = ℏ k m * where m*, h, and k are the effective mass of the charge carrier, the reduced Planck constant, and the wave vector, respectively [116]. Similar to the v, the diffusion coefficient, D, is another character to characterize the diffusion facility of charge carriers in a photocatalyst [117]. D is related to the mobility (μ) of the charge carrier according to the Einstein relation (Eq. (7)), which in turn is connected with the effective collision time (τ) and the effective mass (m*) of the charge carrier (Eq. (8)). (7) D = k B T e μ (8) μ = e τ m * In general, the mobility of the photogenerated carrier is inversely proportional to its effective mass, and the smaller the effective mass, the higher the mobility of the carrier. In addition, the recombination rate of photogenerated electrons and holes is directly dependent on their relative transfer rates. Large differences in transport rates between photogenerated electrons and holes generally correspond to their faster separation and slower recombination rates. Therefore, it is reasonable to use effective mass to evaluate the recombination rate of electron and hole. The effective mass of electrons (m e*) or holes (m h*) is related to the curvature of the CB (for the electrons) or of the VB (for the holes) around the extremum of the band, and the one along the designated directions can be respectively calculated by fitting parabolic functions around the CBM or the VBM according to the following equation (Eq. (9)): (9) m * = ± ℏ 2 ( d 2 E d k 2 ) - 1 where E is the band edge energy as a function of k. The “±” denotes that “+” for the electrons and “−” for the holes [117]. It should be noted that the parabolic fitting region should have an energy difference within 1 meV in a specific direction around CBM or VBM to obtain the validity of the parabolic approximation in the CBM and VBM regions. By fitting VBs and CBs for different crystallographic orientations to determine the effective mass of the carrier, different information can be obtained, such as the anisotropy of the carrier conduction or the potentially high mobility of the carrier. For instance, Abe et al. [118] reported that the minimum effective mass of photogenerated electrons and holes in PbBiO2Cl are 0.36 and 1.44 m 0, respectively. Domen and coworkers [119] found that LaNbON2 has the smallest electron effective mass (m e* = 0.838 m 0) and smallest hole effective mass (m h* = 0.835 m 0), respectively, which are similar to the effective mass values of β-TaON (0.85 m0 for m e* and 0.82 for m h*) reported by Ullah et al. [120]. The effective mass of carriers in the anatase and rutile TiO2 is smaller than that of carriers in PbBiO2Cl and LaNbON2, as shown in Table 1 [34]. This may reveal the reason why anatase and rutile TiO2 have higher photocatalytic activity than PbBiO2Cl and LaNbON2. In addition, from the observation in Table 1, it can be seen that the average effective mass of photoelectrons and holes in anatase is less than that of rutile and brookite, suggesting that the transfer speed of holes and electrons in anatase is the fastest among the three materials. This means that the photoexcited carriers of anatase are easier to migrate from the interior to the surface to participate in the photocatalytic reaction due to its lighter effective mass, which may be the reason why anatase TiO2 shows better photocatalytic performance than rutile and brookite. The mobility of electron hole pairs with significantly different effective masses is not synchronized, which is conducive to reducing photogenerated carrier recombination. For example, Yu et al. [117] found that the effective mass of the photogenerated electrons in wurtzite and zinc-sphalerite CdS is much smaller than the effective mass of the photogenerated holes in all directions. In addition, due to the high symmetry of zinc-blende CdS, the effective masses of electrons and holes in different directions are almost equal. In contrast, the effective masses of electrons and holes in wurtzite CdS are similar only along the Γ→M and Γ→K directions. Meanwhile, the effective carrier mass of wurtzite CdS in the direction of Γ→A is smaller than that in other directions. This indicates that the photogenerated carriers of the wurtzite CdS along Γ→A ([0001]) direction are more easily separated and diffused to the surface of the photocatalyst, thus triggering the photocatalytic reaction. In addition, the effective mass of photogenerated carriers in wurtzite CdS is lower than that in zinc-blende CdS, indicating that the carrier mobility in wurtzite CdS is higher than that in zinc-blende CdS. Therefore, it is easy to understand why wurtzite CdS exhibit better photocatalytic activity than zinc-blende CdS. 3.10 Formation energy (Ef) The formation energy (E f) of a material is a key parameter that influences its stability, reactivity, and properties. In photocatalysis, the E f that researchers focus on mainly involves the formation of two-dimensional materials, defects, impurities, surfaces, interfaces, etc. Take defects or impurities as an example, the general E f of a defect of impurity X in charge state q can be defined as follows [121,122]: (10) E f [ X q ] = E t o t [ X q ] - E b u l k - ∑ i n i μ i + q [ E F + E υ + Δ V ] where E f[X q] is the total energy derived from a supercell calculation with one impurity or defect X in the cell, and E tot[bulk] is the total energy of the perfect bulk host material. ni represents the number of atoms of type i (host or impurity atoms) added to (ni > 0) or removed from (ni < 0) when a defect or impurity forms, and μ i is the chemical potential corresponding to these substances. E F, Eυ , and ΔV are the correction terms for the Fermi level, the energy of the maximum valence band, and the energy zero of the properly arranged defective and undefective supercells. Additionally, the specific forms of the E f are also provided in the following sections. 3.10.1 Formation energy of 2D materials For a single-layer material, the E f is defined relative to the 3D bulk ground-state structure as follows: (11) E f = E 2D/N2D – E 3D/N 3D where E 2D and E 3D are the energies of the single-layer and bulk structure, respectively. N 2D and N 3D are the numbers of atoms in the 2D and 3D unit cells, respectively. Generally, the more negative the Ef value, the more stable the compound is likely to be. Hennig et al. [123] performed studies of the monochalcogenides M A X (M A = Ga and In, X = S, Se, and Te) and dichalcogenides M B X 2 (M B = Nb, Mo, Ta, W, Ti, V, Zr, Hf, and Pt) photocatalysts utilizing a first-principles design approach. Calculated results revealed that the E f of the single-layer MAX materials (0.058–0.092 eV atom−1) are comparable or only slightly larger than the E f of single-layer MoS2 and WS2 (0.077 eV atom−1), while most M B X 2 have similar E f to those of single-layer MoS2. Liu et al. [124] calculated the E f of single-layer Group-IVB nitride halides (MNX, M = Ti, Zr, Hf; X = Cl, Br, I) in different forms and found that the Ef of these MNXs is within 0.05 eV atom−1, as shown in Fig. 9(a) . Though the Ef increases slightly for each cation group, the Ef of each MNX is much smaller than that of GaS or MoS2 (0.058 and 0.077 eV per atom, respectively) mentioned above. This relatively small E f implies the ease of mechanically exfoliating a single-layer MAX, M B X 2, or MNX from their layered bulk counterparts, and some of which have been successfully synthesized, such as MoS2, PtSe2, ZrNBr, etc. [125–127]. 3.10.2 Vacancy formation energy The investigations of the vacancy formation energy (E f,vacancy) of catalysts are important for the guidance of preparing catalysts specifically, especially the structure-sensitive ones. For instance, Zhang et al. [128] investigated the effect of unsaturated Zn sites in ZnCr-layered double hydroxide (ZnCr-LDH) photocatalysts via a facile alkali etching strategy for nitrogen reduction. The calculation results show that ZnCr-LDH containing zinc vacancy is more likely to produce oxygen vacancy (VO) and unsaturated Zn active site than ZnCr-LDH without defect (the E f,vacancy are 1.19 eV versus 2.43 eV, Fig. 9(b)), indicating that unsaturated Zn active site is more easily generated after the introduction of zinc vacancy. In addition to the change of E f,vacancy caused by the self-defect, the formation of defects is also susceptible to the influence of doping heterogeneous atoms. Cheng et al. [129] successfully prepared a red anatase TiO2 photocatalyst by intentionally introducing atomic hydrogen-mediated oxygen vacancies and explored the effects of the hydrogen dopants on the formation of Vo. The calculated E f,vacancy of different defective TiO2 systems as a function of the number of hydrogen dopants shows the larger formation energies of Vo-nH (n = 1, 2, 3, and 4) than Vo, implying the less likely to form Vo-nH than Vo, which in favor of the formation of TO2 with strong absorption band spanning the full spectrum of visible light. Wang and coworkers [130] found that the formation energy of Vo on bare TiO2 was 5.46 eV, while the value decreased to 4.0 eV on Ni/TiO2, as shown in Fig. 9(c). These results verify the assumption that the presence of Ni atoms on the surface of TiO2 decreases the formation energy of the Vo. A similar phenomenon was observed in the Rh-doped TiO2 as reported by Ida et al. [131]. 3.10.3 Doping energy The doping energy (E f,dope) is an important indicator to examine the possibility and stability of crystals doped with different dopants. The E f,dope of a single substitutional impurity atom in a crystal can be estimated as follows: (12) E f,dope = E doped + μ host – μ subs – E perf where E doped and E perf are the calculated energies of the crystal containing substitutional impurity and the perfect crystal, μ host and μ subs are the chemical potential of the host atom and the impurity atom, respectively. Yan et al. [132] designed and synthesized 2D Co-doped g-C3N4 (Co-CN) for photocatalytic degradation of 2-Mercaptobenzothiazole. Calculated results show that all the E f,dope of four doping systems with Co are positive, as exhibited in Fig. 9(d), suggesting that all doping processes are endothermic and non-spontaneous thermodynamic processes. In addition, the results show that the E f,dope of C-doped systems are smaller than those of N-doped systems, which means that Co is more inclined to replace C atoms than N atoms during the doping process, providing additional evidence for the co-doping sites revealed by FT-IR, XPS and Raman analysis. Peng et al. [116] studied the potential mechanism of enhancing photocatalytic activity of N, C and S-doped ZnO by DFT calculation. The calculation results of E f,dope show that the replacement of oxygen atoms in ZnO by the other three doping atoms requires an external energy input. Of the three doping modes, carbon doping requires the largest energy input (12.0 eV), due to the fact that carbon atoms have the most significant electron defect properties. For S doping, a considerable energy input (7.0 eV) is required due to the much larger atomic radius of the sulfur atom. In contrast, N doping requires the least amount of energy (4.7 eV), possibly due to the similarity between nitrogen and oxygen atoms in terms of atomic radius and electronegativity. This should also be a hot spot for the preparation of oxygen nitride photocatalysts by nitrogen-doped oxides [10,59]. 3.10.4 Interface formation energy Fabrication of heterojunction is one of the effective strategies to improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers. The thermal stability and interfacial interaction of one heterostructure can be described by the formation energy of the interface (E f,interface) according to the following equation: (13) E f , interface = 1 S ( E j u n c t i o n - E A - E B ) where E junction, E A, and E B represent the total energies of the formed heterostructure, isolated catalyst A surface model, and catalyst B surface model, respectively, while S represents the area of the interface. Generally, a negative E f,interface indicates that the heterojunction formation is exothermic, which means a stable interface structure can be easily formed. For example, Fan et al. [137] synthesized ZnWO4/BiOI heterostructures with different constituents by chemical bath under mild conditions by adjusting the Zn/Bi molar ratio. The calculated E f,interface based on DFT investigations show that the values for the BiOI(001)-ZnWO4(011) interface and the BiOI(001)-ZnWO4(010) interface are –69.66 meV Å−2 and –66.16 meV Å−2, respectively, indicating the stability of the two hybrid structures. Zhao and coworkers constructed 16 interface models for TiO2 phase junctions by the low-index surfaces of TiO2 with anatase (A(h k l)) and rutile (R(h k l)) phases and analyzed their interfacial energy, microstructure, electronic structure, and properties systematically using DFT calculations [138]. The results show that the E f,interface values of the 16 junctions are relatively small, and the absolute values of the A(110)/R(001) interface are the smallest. At the same time, the absolute values of E f,interface at A(110)/R(100), A(110)/R(110), A(100)/R(001), and A(101)/R(001) junction interfaces were all less than 0.5 eV, indicating that it was relatively easy to form under conventional experimental preparation conditions. In addition, E f,interface of A(110)/R(011) junction has a positive value of 0.157 eV at the interface, indicating that it can be formed spontaneously under conventional experimental preparation conditions. Liu et al. [139] investigated the intrinsic properties of 2D/2D g-C3N4/SnS2 heterojunction, including interfacial energy and etc., using a hybrid density functional approach. The calculated E f,interface of the g-C3N4/SnS2 heterostructure was –0.57 eV, signifying the thermodynamic stability of g-C3N4/SnS2 heterostructure. From another perspective, the calculated E f,interface per unit area (13.0 meV Å−2) is around 20 meV Å−2, illustrating its typical van der Waals interaction characteristic [140]. 3.10.5 Surface energy Owing to photocatalysis reactions occurring on the surface, the stability of the surface, which can be characterized by the surface energy (E surface), significantly affects the efficiency of such reactions. The E surface for the symmetric and stoichiometric termination can be computed using the equation as follows [141]: (14) E s u r f a c e = 1 2 S ( E s l a b - n E b u l k ) where E slab is the total energy of the fully relaxed surface slab, E bulk is the total energy of the bulk per unit cell, n is the number of bulk unit cells contained in the slab, and S is the surface area of each side of the slab. It should be noted that non-stoichiometric surfaces may also appear after cutting the bulk material. For this case, a more general expression of E surface can be described as [142]: (15) E s u r f a c e = 1 2 S ( E s l a b - ∑ i N i μ i , s u r f a c e + P Δ V - T Δ S ) where Ni and μi are the number of the corresponding atoms and the chemical potential in the surface, respectively. ΔV is the volume change due to surface relaxation, which is generally ignorable under the environment pressure P; ΔS is mostly the vibrational entropy change induced by the surface cleavage from the bulk structure. As a general convention, the last two terms of PΔV and TΔS in Eq. (15) are often disregarded. The key to control the formation of crystal faces is to change the relative stability of each crystal face in the process of crystal growth, which is essentially determined by the surface energy of the crystal face. For instance, Domen and coworkers prepared LaNbON2 photocatalyst by nitriding plate-like LaKNaNbO5 precursors and found that the transformation of LaKNaNbO5 into LaNbON2 along the [010] direction occurred due to their low lattice mismatch, leading to {010} facets exposed on the surface of plate-like LaNbON2 during nitridation [119]. DFT calculated results exhibit the E surface of {010} facets (5.74 J m−2) was greater than that of {100} facets (4.10 J m−2), as shown in Fig. 9(e), showing that the former is not stable. This is partly due to the large proportion of O and N atoms on the {010} plane that are undercoordinated. Ye et al. [133] reported that the single-crystalline Ag3PO4 rhombic dodecahedrons with only {110} facets exposed exhibited higher photocatalytic activity for the degradation of methyl orange and RhB dyes than the cubes bounded entirely by {100} facets. The E surface calculated by DFT shows that the surface energy of {110} (1.31 J m−2) is higher than that of {100} (1.12 J m−2), indicating that the surface energy of {110} is more active than that of {100}. Further calculations of the oxygen reduction {110} and {100} surfaces shown in Fig. 9(f) show that the {110} surface is more prone to oxygen vacancies than the {100} surface. These calculations show that each Ag3PO4 rhombohedral dodecahedron has 12 highly active {110} faces and a high density of corners, edges and defects, which may significantly increase the number of catalytic active sites on its surface and promote the adsorption of organic molecules at these sites, resulting in higher photocatalytic activity for the degradation of organic dyes. Selloni et al. [143] investigated the structure and energetics of several low-index surfaces of anatase, and revealed the order of the average surface energies as follows: E surface{001} (0.90 J m−2) > E surface{100} (0.53 J m−2) > E surface{101} (0.44 J m−2). The high E surface of {001} facets is considered to be originated from the 100% 5-fold-coordinated titanium atoms (Ti5c) as compared to 50% Ti5c on the {101} surface [144], and the related activities have also been verified by a series of photocatalytic experiments [145,146]. Surface-adsorbed ligands play key roles in changing the E surface of crystal facets and thus the percentage of facets during the fabrication [147]. To better understand the controllable growth of single-crystalline anatase TiO2 with various facets exposed via a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method, Faungnawakij et al. [134] performed DFT calculations to gain insight into the roles of F– and H+ with various coverages. The results show that the surface roughness of {110} surface of rutilite (E surface-R110 = 0.60 J m−2) is smaller than that of {101} surface of anatase (E surface-A101 = 0.67 J m−2) without F− (0.0 monolayer, ML). With the increasing of the adsorption amount of F-ion on the surface, the adsorption amount of F-ion on the surface decreases, but the effect on the anatase {101} surface is more obvious. Furthermore, E surface-A101 is significantly lower than E surface-R110 when F− covers about 0.7 ML, suggesting that F− ions induce a lower surface energy of the anatase {101} surface than the rutile {110} surface, resulting in the rutile phase changing to anatase when a sufficient amount of F− is added. Subsequently, the effect of H+ with different coverage on the anatase {101} and {001} surfaces is investigated, where the coverage of F− is fixed at about 0.5 ML, chosen because the surfaces of A(101) and A(001) surfaces are relatively close together when H+ is not present on the surface. It can be seen from Fig. 9(g) that under different H+ coverage, the surface area of (001) facet is lower than that of (101) facet, and the gap between them gradually becomes larger with the increase of H+ coverage. This means that for anatase TiO2, the larger amount of H+ is conducive to (001) crystal plane growth, but not (101) crystal plane growth. Furthermore, when the fixed coverage of F− varies between 0.5 and 1.0 ML and the coverage of H+ is 1ml, the E surface of A(001) is lower than that of A(101), further indicating that large amounts of H+ favor the growth of (001) rather than (101). All the calculated results agree with the experimental observations carried out by the authors. Inorganic semiconductors are prone to reacting with suspended bonds, and the surface properties of metal-organic frames (MOFs) are conceptually different compared to inorganic semiconductors because of the presence of multiple bonds, such as hydrogen, coordination, or covalent bonds [148,149]. Considering the molecular properties, truncation occurs at the weakest coordination bond of the skeleton, and the unsaturated site is coordinated through the donor. Therefore, the general principle that the minimal consumption of energy in breaking bonds should be noted when creating surface slabs for MOFs [150]. For instance, Sun et al. [151] constructed a series of facets of NH2-MIL-125(Ti) MOFs with a minimal number of coordination bonds per surface area and no broken covalent bonds. Calculated E surface shows that the {110} facet has a higher value of 1.18 J m−2 than that of the {001} (0.74 J m−2), {100} (0.81 J m−2) and {111} (0.51 J m−2) facets. This difference can be attributed to a larger proportion of exposed metal clusters, which can serve as active sites for photocatalysis. Zhong and coworkers [152] built the directional charge-transfer channels in a direct Z-scheme system over MIL-88B(Fe) and UiO-66-NH2 to facilitate CO2 photoreduction and employed DFT calculations to investigate the growth mechanism of MIL-on-2UiO-NH2. Calculated results show that the {111} facet of UiO-66-NH2 has the lowest E surface (0.12 J m−2) than that of the {100} (0.35 J m−2) and {101} (0.24 J m−2) facets, while the E surface for MIL-88B(Fe) are as follows: {100} (0.01 J m−2) < {101} (0.15 J m−2) < {001} (0.20 J m−2). These results suggest that the high active {001} facet of MIL-88(Fe) is more likely to integrate with UiO-66-NH2, which agrees with the observations of the absence of {001} facet of MIL-88B(Fe) in XRD patterns. 3.11 Surface adsorption During heterogeneous catalysis, including photocatalytic reactions, the adsorbates should be bound with the catalyst with an appropriate adsorption strength [153]. The best catalyst should have a moderate strength in binding atoms and molecules: not too weak for the activation of the reactants and not too strong for the desorption of the products, which can be characterized by the adsorption energy (E ads), expressed by the following formula: (16) E ads = E tot – E slab – E adsorbate where E tot, E slab, and E adsorbate are the energy of the adsorption complex, the catalyst slab, and the isolated adsorbate, respectively. Conceivably, the desorption energy is equated to the negative adsorption energy. In general, a negative E ads signifies that adsorbate adsorption is stable. It is known that the H atom adsorption is a critical step for photocatalytic H2 evolution. Zhu et al. [135] fabricated a Pt-S3 protrusion tetrahedron coordination structure through stabilizing ultralow Pt cocatalyst onto the basal plane of hexagonal ZnIn2S4 nanosheets, which exhibited an enhanced H2 evolution yield rate under visible light irradiation. Fig. 9(h) shows the calculated relationship between the E ads and H coverage ratio of H atom, where the adsorption strength of H decreases with the increase of the number of H atom adsorbed. For the case of three H atoms adsorbed on a single Pt atom, the three H atoms are symmetrically distributed around the Pt site, and the corresponding adsorption energy is 0.543 eV per H. When the number of H atoms reaches 4, the adsorption configuration will become a situation where H2 dimer and two isolated H atoms are formed. The adsorption energy is 0.436 eV per H, which may be the reason for promoting the desorption of 4H on the Pt atom and the easy formation of H2. For photocatalytic N2 fixation, the optimized E ads of N2 also is a critical consideration [154,155]. Zhang and coworkers [156] reported that copper-doped ultrathin TiO2 nanosheets with an abundance of oxygen vacancies and intrinsic compressive strain can act as a novel photocatalyst with an enhanced activity of reduction of N2 to NH3 in water.
