Calculations show this Cu-doped TiO2 nanosheet has an E ads value of −0.37 eV, higher than that of pure TiO2 (−0.25 eV) and VO-doped TiO2 (−0.17 eV), suggesting that adsorption is most favorable on the surface of TiO2-VO-Strain, which is certified by the experimental characterizations such as the N2 absorption-desorption isotherms and N2 temperature-programmed desorption. The increased E ads may lead to improved charge transfer between TiO2 and N2, weakened N≡N triple bond, and consequently enhanced N2 activation and fixation. Dong et al. [136] prepared Bi2O2CO3 (BOC) nanosheets (Bi@OV-BOC) modified with bismuth metal nanoparticles with oxygen vacancy for photocatalytic NO emission reduction. As shown in Fig. 9(i), NO → NO2 → NO3 − exists a clear energy barrier on BOC, indicating that the process requires external energy to trigger, thus hindering the photocatalytic oxidation of NO (as described above). Although there is no NO2 → NO3 − energy barrier on OV-BOC, the presence of NO → NO2 energy barrier (0.19 eV) will also affect the actual photocatalytic performance, because the formation of transitional intermediates is hindered during the reaction process, thus slowing down the photocatalytic oxidation of NO to NO3 − (middle) reaction rate. The interaction of Bi metal nanoparticles with the oxygen vacancy on Bi@OV-BOC promotes the activation of the reaction and significantly reduces the energy barrier (NO → NO2, and NO2 → NO3 −, way below). The results show that the transformation of pollutant (NO) to final product (NO3 −) at Bi@OV-BOC is very favorable, which is consistent with the experimental results. The adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst surface has an important effect on the formation of reduction products. For instance, Wong and colleagues [157] reported a direct all-solid Z-scheme system consisting of sea urchin-like α-Fe2O3 and g-C3N4 nanosheets to enhance CO2 reduction activity. The adsorption energies calculations reveal that g-C3N4 and α-Fe2O3 exhibit relatively weak and strong CO2 affinity (E ads = −0.317 eV and −3.072 eV), respectively, while a moderate E ads −3.072 eV can be obtained for α-Fe2O3/g-C3N4, suggesting that the introduction of α-Fe2O3 can significantly improve the CO2 adsorption capacity of g-C3N4. In addition, a similar E ads sequence can also be observed for the CO adsorption. The comprehensive utilization of the strong adsorption energy of CO2 on the α-Fe2O3 surface and the weak CO adsorption ability of g-C3N4 would be ascribed to the enhanced activity of photoreduction of CO2 to CO over the Z-scheme hybrid material. To investigate the underlying mechanism of the high selectivity of CH4 production, Zhang and coworkers [158] assembled Au/TiO2/W18O49 sandwich-like plasmonic heterostructure for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The DFT study shows that C and O atoms in CO molecules can bind to Ti and Au atoms respectively in the Au/TiO2 heterogenous interface region to form stable Ti-C-O-Au intermediates with CO-E ads of −1.16 eV. In the case of W18O49/TiO2 hetero-interface, relatively strong adsorption with an E ads of −2.16 eV was demonstrated to result from the bonding of W atoms in the W18O49 with the O atoms in the CO molecule. The strong adsorption of CO would result in the protonation of CO* intermediate to form the COH* intermediate rather than desorption for releasing CO, thereby boosting the continuous protonation reactions of CO* to generate the COH*/HCO* intermediates as well as the final product of CH4. 4 Photocatalytic reactions The DFT calculation can clarify the reaction mechanism in the photocatalysis process and the internal relationship between the catalytic performance and the active site, so that researchers can more intuitively understand the structure-activity relationship at the atomic level, and further realize the direct regulation of the photocatalyst. For catalytic reactions involving multiple electron transfers, one step of each electron transfer is considered an elemental reaction, whose energy change can be calculated as Gibbs free energy by the common equation (Eq. (17)) developed by Nørskov [159]: (17) Δ G = G f i n a l - G i n i t i a l = ( E f i n a l + E Z P E , f i n a l - T S f i n a l ) - ( E i n i t i a l + E Z P E , i n i t i a l - T S i n i t i a l ) Δ E + Δ E Z P E - T Δ S where ΔE and ΔS are the energy of the reaction (ΔE = E final – E initial) and the differences in entropy, E ZPE and T are the vibrational zero-point energy and the temperature of the reaction, respectively. During the process of reaction, it is also important to consider transition state searches and confirmations as they play a crucial role in understanding reaction mechanisms and kinetics. Transition states are critical points along the reaction pathway where the reactants transform into products, and they represent the highest energy point on the potential energy surface. Various computational methods, such as transition state optimization algorithms like the nudged elastic band (NEB) method [160], the climbing image nudged elastic band (CINEB) [161], the dimer method [162], etc. can be used to locate transition states. Typically, the NEB method involves constructing a series of images (interpolated structures) between the initial and final states of a reaction and optimizing their positions iteratively to find the minimum energy pathway, while the CINEB, an extension of the NEB method, includes a climbing image to locate the transition state more accurately, which is subjected to an additional force that moves it uphill along the energy gradient, allowing it to converge to the true transition state. The Dimer method is another computational technique used for locating transition states in chemical reactions. It involves perturbing the system along a predefined direction in configuration space and iteratively optimizing the geometry to find the saddle point corresponding to the transition state. While transition states are crucial for understanding reaction mechanisms and kinetics, the focus in DFT calculations is often on determining the relative energies of intermediates and products to assess the feasibility and thermodynamics of the reaction. 4.1 Hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) Water photocatalysis has the advantages of using water and sunlight as raw materials, no emission of greenhouse gases and other polluting gases, and is considered to be a clean and efficient method for hydrogen production. The photocatalytic process of water includes two half reactions: hydrogen evolution (HER, Eq. (13)) and oxygen evolution (OER, Eq. (15)). The reaction pathway of HER consists of four steps, as shown in Fig. 10(a) , namely, water absorption, hydrolytic dissociation, formation of H* intermediates and H2 precipitation [163]. Unlike the electrocatalytic HER progress, the free energy calculations in photocatalytic HER need to account for the additional energy input from light to drive the reaction, which could influence the kinetics of the HER; whereas electrocatalytic HER are primarily governed by applied potential and reaction conditions [164,165]. Moreover, in photocatalytic HER progress, pure semiconductors always have large surface overpotentials or high activation energy for water reduction, for instance, the calculated |ΔG H| values for pure TiO2 and pure g-C3N4 can respectively be as high as 3.42 and 3.71 eV [166,167], leading to the sluggish activity for H2 generation. Varieties of strategies have been implemented to overcome these drawbacks, such as modifying with suitable cocatalysts, doping with foreign elements, etc. [17]. In this case, the photocatalytic HER activity of the cocatalyst/semiconductor system depends on the HER performance of the cocatalyst. (18) 2H+ (aq) + 2e− → H2 (g) (19) Δ E = E H - slab - E slab - 1 2 E H 2 Zhang et al. [168] designed nickel-iron bimetallic phosphide (NiFeP) onto graphitic carbon nitride (NiFeP/g-C3N4) to improve the photocatalytic HER performance, and employed the absolute value of free energy, |ΔG H|, as a major descriptor of the HER activity. The calculated ΔG H values (Fig. 10(b)) are −0.29 and −0.72 eV for the single metal cocatalysts Ni2P and FeP, and the corresponding catalyst-OHad free energies (ΔG H2O) are 0.64 and 0.36 eV, respectively. These results demonstrate that the water dissociation would be impeded with the high ΔG H2O for Ni2P, and the H2 evolution would be hindered with the high |ΔG H| for FeP, both of them can lead to sluggish HER kinetics [169]. In contrast, the ΔG H2O and ΔG H values for the NiFeP/g-C3N4 are 0.11  and −0.23  eV, respectively, suggesting its favorite catalytic activity from the free energy diagrams, which is consistent with the experimental results of H2 evolution. Ye et al. [170] reported an intimate contact structure between a noble-metal-free cocatalyst NiCo2S4 and semiconductor ZnIn2S4 nanoflower to boost the separation of photogenerated carriers as well as H2 generation. By calculating the Gibbs free energy change of the reaction on ZnIn2S4 (Fig. 10(c)), the largest increase in free energy (rate-determining step, which is abbreviated to RDS) was found as the step of water dissociation to produce the hydrogen proton (H*) with a ΔG value of 2.94 eV. After loading with NiCo2S4, the free energy barrier of RDS decreased significantly to 1.62 eV, indicating that the construction of the composite system is extremely important for activating the water-absorbing H–OH bond by reducing the apparent activation energy of water overflow. A similar phenomenon is also reported by Wang and coworkers [171], who fabricated a MoS2/CdS hybrid structure for photocatalytic water splitting. Calculated Gibbs free energy exhibits a lower Gibbs free energy vibration of the water dissociation (−0.051 eV) and ΔG H* (0.002 eV) for MoS2/CdS than that for pure CdS (−0.131 and −0.097 eV), respectively. The results show that the loading of molybdenum disulfide is conducive to the breaking of H–OH bond and the contraction of proton adsorption barrier, implying MoS2 is an effective cocatalyst to bring a considerable positive effect on the catalytic HER performance of CdS. The above investigations demonstrate that the overall HER pathway can be summarized by a three-state diagram, composed of an initial state H+ + e−, an intermediate adsorbed H*, and a final product 1/2H2, which known as the Volmer-Heyrovský mechanism [173,174]. In this case, the Gibbs free energy of atomic hydrogen adsorbed on a catalyst, ΔG H, which can be calculated using equations Eqs.(17) and (19), is a key descriptor of HER activity. In particular, the rapid adsorption and release kinetics of hydrogen atoms are very favorable for the practical application of highly efficient HER. In other words, the optimal HER activity ΔG H of the catalyst is close to zero (ΔG H ~ 0), indicating that the free energy of adsorption H is close to the free energy of the reactant or product [175]. Lower ΔG H will result in strong bonding of the adsorbed hydrogen, while higher ΔG H will make the bonding of the proton to the catalyst surface too weak, both of which will result in slower HER kinetics. For instance, Tian et al. [176] reported that Co-doped MoS2 can realize extremely efficient photocatalytic H2 production of g-C3N4 nanosheets in an alkalescent environment. They calculated the ΔG H on the targeted catalytic sites, and found that the ΔG H for Mo and S sites of MoS2/g-C3N4 is −0.456 and 0.314 eV. Contrastingly, the ΔG H for Co, Mo, and S sites of Co-MoS2/g-C3N4 are −0.143, −0.197, and 0.231 eV, respectively, which are very close to −0.09 eV on Pt [177]. These phenomena manifest that Co-MoS2/g-C3N4 is catalytically highly active, which is in accordance with its relatively high HER performance. This result also demonstrates the Co ions incorporated into the lattice of MoS2 could induce the distortion of MoS2 crystal to effectively reduce the ΔG H for HER, in line with the previous investigations [178]. Besides the cocatalyst modifying, foreign element doping is another strategy to improve the photocatalytic HER activity with an ideal |ΔG H| value. For instance, Zhai and coworkers [179] reported that nitrogen-defective and sulfur-doped g-C3N4 (S-g-C3N4-D) possess high photocatalytic HER performance. DFT calculations show that the optimal value of |ΔG H| for S-g-C3N4-D at the S active site is 0.24 eV, which is almost zero compared to the optimal values of g-C3N4 (−1.72 eV) and g-C3N4-D (−1.99 eV). These results confirm that the simultaneous introduction of N defect and S dopant has a significant effect on the improvement of HER catalytic performance. In a recent theoretical study, Vega et al. [172] presented a novel computational screening study of single transition metal (TM)-doped, and dual TMs-doped on CdS (110) surfaces via DFT calculations. Gibbs free energy changes collected in Fig. 10(e) reveal pristine CdS (110) surface has a very high |ΔG H| value (1.11 eV) compared to the results of TM-doped surfaces, indicating that pristine CdS is not highly efficient for the HER. This is in agreement with the experimental observations [180]. Among all TM-modified CdS (denoted as TM@CdS), Pt@CdS (0.18 eV), Rh@CdS (0.13 eV), and Pd@CdS (0.11 eV) surfaces show minimum values of |ΔG H|, while Ag and Au @CdS systems show quite large values of |ΔG H| (values of −0.82 and 1.05 eV, respectively), demonstrating their different capabilities for reducing the reaction overpotential of HER among these TM@CdS surfaces. Furthermore, they also calculated the ΔG H of dual-metal doped CdS with selected six types of TMs (Co, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, and Pt) as the modifiers, because they exhibit a positive effect on the reduction of |ΔG H| for pure CdS. As revealed in Fig. 10(f), the calculated results for the most stable configuration of H adsorption show that Rh-Rh, Co-Pt, Pd-Pt, and Co-Rh@CdS show relatively small Gibbs free energies of H adsorption (−0.018, −0.075, 0.077, and −0.084, respectively), demonstrating their potential to be excellent HER catalyst. It should be noted that as for the TM@CdS and TM1-TM2@CdS surfaces with H* adsorption, the H* prefers to be adsorbed at the top site of TM atoms, and there is a strong interaction between the H* atom and d orbitals of TM atoms. These results suggest that these metals could act as effective active sites of HER. In addition to the foreign element doping, the H coverage also affects the ΔG H significantly. Qiao et al. [52] developed a novel MXene material, Ti3C2 nanoparticles, as a highly efficient co-catalyst. Prior to experimental investigations, DFT calculations were employed to shed light on the intrinsic properties of Ti3C2. ΔG H results show that pure Ti3C2 and F-terminated Ti3C2 respectively exhibit largely negative (−0.927 eV) and largely positive (1.995 eV) values, both of which are unfavorable for HER. For the O-terminated Ti3C2, as shown in Fig. 10(d), smaller |ΔG H| can be calculated with values of −0.316−0.527 eV at different H* coverage, and the optimal one can reach a near-zero value of |ΔG H| = 0.00283 when H* coverage is 1/2. This value clearly indicates the remarkable HER activity results from the O-terminated Ti3C2 from the viewpoint of thermodynamics, which was verified by the photocatalytic H2-production experiment using CdS as a photocatalyst. 4.2 Oxygen evolution reactions (OER) Compared with HER, which consists of two electron transfer processes, oxygen evolution (OER), which consists of four proton-coupled electron transfer reactions, is considered to be the key reaction and bottleneck of photocatalytic water decomposition due to its high overpotential and low efficiency. A variety of mechanisms have been proposed for OER, depending on a number of factors ranging from the material to the reaction environment [181,182]. One of the widely used mechanisms for the OER is that oxygen molecules are formed via a surface OOH intermediate (OOH*). As shown in Fig. 11(a) , the OER proceeds through the following sequential elementary steps with different intermediates, which was proposed by Nørskov [183]: H2O molecule dissociates into OH* and H*, deprotonation reaction of OH* to form O*, O* binds with a second H2O to form OOH*, and OOH* undergoes deprotonation reaction to form O2* for O2(g) evolution. In general, the absorption energy (E ads) of H2O, as well as those oxygen-containing species, is crucial to trigger the OER and carry out the whole OER process. The changes in free energy (ΔG) of these four steps are denoted as ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, and ΔG 4, respectively. Commonly, the theoretical overpotential (η OER), which reflects the reaction kinetics as a sign of the energy barrier or activation energy in the OER reaction, is used to evaluate the OER activity of a catalyst. The η OER is defined as η OER = max(ΔG 1, ΔG 2, ΔG 3, and ΔG 4)/e − 1.23 V [184]. (20) 2H2O(l) + 4h+ → 4H+ (aq) + O2(g) At present, the development of efficient methods to promote the slow kinetics of OER is still highly demanding. Surface modification, surface polarons, etc. have been proven to be effective methods in tailoring the surface electronic structures as well as catalytic OER properties [185–187]. For instance, Liu et al. [188] demonstrated that surface modification with Cl− can drastically enhance photocatalytic water oxidation over BiVO4. In order to understand the mechanism of water oxidation reaction of modified BiVO4 system, the effects of Cl− modification on water oxidation process were discussed. The results show that the formation of OH* radicals with an energy of 3.30 eV on unmodified BiVO4 is the RDS of water oxidation, as shown in Fig. 11(b). In contrast, on Cl− modified BiVO4 (BiVO4-Cl), the free energy can be significantly reduced to 1.67 eV. In addition, the energy of RDS conversion to *O is 2.18 eV, indicating that the oxidation process of water on the BiVO4-Cl surface is smoother. This transformation of RDS suggests that Cl− modification leads to a change in the reaction pathway and a significant reduction in the energy barrier. In recent years, oxynitrides have been widely investigated for photocatalysis applications [10,194]. The properties of oxynitrides are sensitive to the local surface structure and oxygen/nitrogen ordering. Moreover, doping and strain engineering also show effective potential in tailoring the surface electronic structures and catalytic properties. For example, Castelli et al. [189] used DFT calculations to study the strain of Ca and Sr and cationic doping to optimize the OER theoretical overpotential of BaTaO2N. Gibbs free energy calculations reveal that the RDS is the formation of OOH with a free-energy difference of 2.87 eV for the clean TaO2N-terminated (100) surface, which results in a theoretical η OER of 1.64 V. For the case of full O coverage, theoretical η OER of 0.74 and 0.43 V were calculated when the reaction occurs from the O atom on the top of the Ta1 and Ta2 atom, respectively, as shown in inset in Fig. 11(c). This may be because that more Ta with adsorbed O on the bridge site are oxidized, resulting in weakened and broken Ta and O double bond for easy formation of the Ta-OOH intermediate (RDS), thus leading to a lower theoretical η OER. On the TaON-terminated (001) surface, the RDS is the formation of OOH resulting in a theoretical η OER of 0.97 V, which is lower than that of the corresponding (100) surface (1.64 V). This phenomenon is similar to the surface reaction on Sr2TaO3N [195]. Moreover, as exhibited in Fig. 11(d), the theoretical η OER can be decreased from 0.97 to 0.69 V under 4% tensile uniaxial strain for the clean surface, while it can be changed from 0.78 to 0.59 V for the full OH covered surface. Furthermore, Sr- and Ca-doping can slightly reduce the theoretical η OER from 0.97 to 0.90 V and 0.88 V, respectively, which may result from the increased ΔG O* − ΔG OH* due to the doping. This study demonstrated that the OER catalytic properties can be optimized only by controlling anion ordering, strain, and doping. Besides inorganic semiconductor materials, organic- inorganic or organic-organic hybrid crystalline porous solid materials (MOFs or COFs) have also been widely exploited for photocatalytic water oxidation [196–198]. Although the mechanism that oxygen molecules are formed via a surface OOH intermediate (OOH*) has been widely adopted for inorganic semiconductor materials, while another process that the oxygen molecules are formed via an adsorbed OO intermediate (OO*) has been usually considered as the most reactive path for the MOFs or COFs materials, as shown in Fig. 11(e). This is mainly due to the existence of adjacent dual-site in the frameworks, such as sp 2 hybridized carbon in phenyl species. A typical example is that β-ketoamine COFs show pretty good photocatalytic water oxidation activity [199]. Two possible OER rings were evaluated using discrete Fourier transform (DFT) calculations, including unit-point and two-site processes, forming OOH* and O*OH*, and results demonstrate that the RDS for the single-site reactions is OOH* formation while the step for dual-site reactions is OO* formation at pH = 7 and U = 0, respectively. The activation energy of the rate-determining step for the single-site process (ΔG OOH* – ΔG O*) is higher than that for the dual-site process (ΔG OO* – ΔG O*OH*), suggesting the dual-site reaction path is considered as the most reactive path. Similar phenomena can also be observed in other OER reactions catalyzed by COFs, such as TpPa-1-COF [200], covalent heptazine-based frameworks (CHFs) [201], etc. 4.3 Oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) The ORR can be divided into two categories depending on the number of overall electrons transferred during the reaction, that is, 4e− ORR to generate O2-species (H2O or OH−) or 2e− ORR to generate hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) [202,203]. Actually, the ORR process is very complicated owing to the several possible transformations between different intermediates, such as O*, OH*, and OOH* species, as schematically shown in Fig. 11(f), which could be generated during oxygen reaction under common ORR conditions [191]. It is well known that the overall rate of a chemical reaction is often determined by the most energy-demanding step. The DFT calculated ORR free energy diagram allows these steps to be identified as a function of the external potential (U), where the reduction of OOH* and OH* to form the end product H2O2 or H2O is generally considered a limiting ORR step that determines the reaction rate and pathway. Compared with the full reduction of O2 in the field of electrocatalysis (e.g., fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and certain electrolyzers) [204], the generation of H2O2 form ORR is more concerned in photocatalysis based on semiconductors [205,206]. Metal-free g-C3N4 is recognized as a potential catalyst for the photocatalytic production of H2O2 because of its good stability and easy preparation [207–209]. Recently, Cabot et al. [192] reported an oxygen-doped tubular g-C3N4 with uniformly dispersed nickel nanoparticles (Ni/OtCN) for efficient photocatalytic H2O2 generation. In this study, DFT-based calculations were performed to investigate the mechanism of photocatalytic H2O2 generation, and results reveal that the ΔG for the reduction of OOH* and OH* on bulk C3N4 (bCN) were 1.42 and 1.35 eV, respectively (Fig. 11(g)). The similar ΔG for OOH* and OH* on bCN demonstrates the simultaneous occurrence of the two-electron and four-electron pathways. After being doped with oxygen, the ΔG values for the reduction of the two intermediates on OtCN are separately decreased to 0.72 and 0.99 eV, and further decreased to 0.35 and 0.66 eV with the introduction of Ni particles. The lower ΔG values obtained for Ni/OtCN reveal enhanced reaction kinetics of ORR. Meanwhile, the ΔG values of OOH* reduction were also found to be significantly lower than those of OH* reduction in OtCN or Ni/OtCN samples, suggesting that the 2e– ORR pathway is more likely than the 4e– ORR pathway. These calculated results are in agreement with the experimental data obtained, which further proves that oxygen doping and Ni loading make the catalyst more inclined to 2e– ORR, which can significantly improve the efficiency of H2O2 generation. Similar DFT calculations were performed on dual-heteroatom incorporated polymeric C3N4, which illustrate that the oxygen and potassium dual-heteroatom incorporated polymeric C3N4 (O/K-CN) is more favorable for the adsorption of dioxygen molecular to promote the formation of the key intermediate species OOH* than other catalysts (pure polymeric C3N4 and single-heteroatom incorporated polymeric C3N4), thus causing decreasing energy barrier of ORR for O/K-CN to produce H2O2 [210]. Besides the famous Gibbs free energy, the thermodynamic limit potential (U L) is defined as the highest potential when the free energy of all reaction steps falls [211]. In a recent study, Hu et al. [193] established four model structures, representing the original g-C3N4 (CN), oxygen-doped CN (OCN), cyano-laced CN (NCN) and cyano-and heteroatomic oxygen CN (NOCN), with both marginal and basal active sites (as shown in Fig. 11(i)). In order to study the role and function of heteratomic oxygen doping and the introduction of cyanide group, it will guide the design of efficient catalyst for the production of PC H2O2 by 2e– ORR process [193]. Fig. 11(h) shows a theoretical volcano map using U L as a function of H2O2 to generate ΔG OOH*, where areas shaded in pink indicate areas with high selectivity for H2O2 products. In general, the higher the U L, the lower the overpotential, and the higher the activity of H2O2 generation. The results show that NOCE-E-O4 has the highest 2e– ORR activity with a maximum U L of 0.58 V, but its structure is unstable due to its formation energy up to 3.5 eV. The U L and formation energy of NOCN-E-O5 are 0.53 and 0.76 eV respectively, both lower than NOCE-E-O4. At the same time, NOCN-E-O5 has strong O2 adsorption capacity and is the active site for H2O2 generation. These results indicate that NOCN-E-O5 is the most active site in 2e– ORR, which is confirmed by experimental observations. 4.4 Carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) Converting CO2 into a range of high value-added products through CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR) is gaining increasing attention as it is another way to solve energy shortages and environmental problems [212,213]. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction is a clean, economical and environmentally friendly method to convert CO2 into hydrocarbon fuel using solar energy. Considering that CO2 is one of the chemically stable forms of carbon, the photocatalysis of CO2RR is challenging and usually requires a cocatalyst to activate CO2 [214,215] The mechanism of CO2RR, as exhibited in Fig. 12(a) , is fairly complex owing to the diverse reactant used (e.g., H2, H2O, CH4, CH3OH, etc.) and the possibility of the formation of multiple products [216–219]. Therefore, a basic understanding of the CO2RR mechanism is necessary to design catalysts that selectively convert CO2 into the desired product. A growing number of studies combine experimental characterization with DFT calculations to determine the mechanism of CO2RR catalysis, revealing that the catalytic activity and selectivity of CO2RR products are mainly determined by the adsorption energy of key intermediates [220,221]. Taking the conversion of CO2 to CO as an example, it generally undergoes four elementary reaction steps with the carboxyl intermediate (i.e., COOH*) [222,223]. Xiang et al. [224] observed that crystalline g-C3N4 nanorod-supported copper single atoms (Cu-CCN) enable photocatalytic conversion of CO2 to CO with an exciting rate and a high selectivity under the absence of any cocatalyst or sacrificial agent and DFT calculation was used to study the relationship between active sites and product selectivity. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the adsorbed CO2 on Cu-CCN samples is initially hydrogenated to generate COOH*, which is an exothermic reaction with an energy change of 0.80 eV. The COOH* can be subsequently transformed to CO* or CHO*, which is a key intermediate to generate CO or CH4, respectively. The DFT results show that the transition from COOH* to CO* is thermodynamically favorable, with an energy release of 1.27 eV, while the transition from COOH* to CHO* requires an energy consumption of 0.37 eV, indicating that the reduction of CO2 to CO via pathway 1 is easier than the reduction to CH4 via pathway II. Other reported photocatalysts, such as Cs3Bi2Br9/In4SnS8, Cu/TiO2, Zn2GeO4, etc. are also in favor of the transition from COOH* to CO* rather than CHO* intermediate to result in the CO as the main product [225–227]. CH4 is another gas C1 product of CO2 reduction with eight electron transfer, which results from a competing reaction of CO generation. Sulfur-deficient CuIn5S8, Au1/ZnIn2S4, BiVO4/WO3, etc. have gained increased interest as CO2RR to CH4 catalysts [228–230]. A recent study reported by Guo et al. [231] showed that CO2 could be effectively reduced to CH4 on dual-vacancy Nb2O5/g-C3N4 junction (VO,N-NBCN), where the rate-breaking step energy required is 0.695 eV to generate COOH*. As shown in Fig. 12(c), COOH* is continuously transformed into the key intermediate CO*, and there are two reaction ways: first, CO* is immediately desorbed from the catalyst surface to produce CO (path I); second, CO* is protonated to produce CHO*(path II), which is a prerequisite for subsequent hydrogenation to eventually produce CH4. In this process, the Gibbs free energy of CHO* formation (∆G CHO*) is smaller than the desorption energy of the CO molecules (∆G *+CO), implying that the VO,N-NBCN is more conducive to the protonation of CO* into CHO* than to the desorption of CO molecules from its surface. This accounts for its high selectivity for visible-light-driven CO2 reduction to CH4 in experimental tests. Similar to inorganic semiconductors, organic-based materials also play a novel role in photoreducing CO2. One typical example is a redox-active conjugated microporous polymer (TPA-PQ) by assimilating an electron donor (tris(4-ethynylphenyl)amine, TPA) and an acceptor (phenanthraquinone, PQ) reported by Maji et al. [232]. DFT calculations showed that the redox-active PQ moiety acts as the active catalytic site to collect photogenerated electrons to adopt CO2 and carries out the CO2RR. As shown in Fig. 12(d), CO2 adopted to PQ to form the CO2-bound intermediate as [TPA-PQ–-CO2]− firstly, which occurs to afford a COOH* intermediate, is found to be the RDS for CO2 to CO. The following step is COOH* → CO* with a ΔG = –3.29 eV. Subsequently, proton-coupled reduction of the key intermediate CO* to the CHO* was found to be highly exoergic (ΔG = –1.72 eV) as compared to the endoergic desorption (ΔG = 0.19 eV) of CO, which could drive the CO2 reduction further toward the formation of CH4 with the proton-coupled reductions of CHO* → CH2O* (ΔG = –1.33 eV) → CH3O* (ΔG = –1.95 eV) → CH3OH* (ΔG = –1.56 eV) → CH3* (ΔG = –2.53 eV) → CH4 (ΔG = –3.66 eV). During the reduction of CO2 to CH4, the formed CH3OH* also can be desorbed from the surface of the catalyst to generate a liquid C1 product, CH3OH [233,234]. The difference in final products are likely originated from the different adsorption energies of some formed key intermediate [235,236]. In a recent study, Kung et al. [237] developed g-C3N4 covalently linked to melamine-resorcinol-formaldehyde microsphere polymers (CN-MRF) as a photocatalyst to efficiently realize CO2RR to CH3OH. Gibbs free energy calculations reveal that the hydrogenation step of CH2OH* to CH3OH* shows the highest barrier of 2.35 eV among the sequential hydrogenation of CO* to form the various adsorbed CH x O species, as exhibited in Fig. 12(e). In comparison, a higher theoretical energy barrier of 2.81 eV is needed to further hydrogenation of CH2OH* to CH4*, suggesting the formation of CH3OH is more favorable than the formation of CH4, which explains the observed high selectivity of methanol. Similar to the formation of CH4 from CO2RR, there is a different mechanism for the generation of CH3OH. For instance, Zhao et al. [241] reported hexagonal tungsten bronze (M 0.33WO3, M = K, Rb, Cs) presented excellent photocatalytic CO2RR performance with high production selectivity toward CH3OH. Stepwise Gibbs free energy calculations show that the COOH* can be reacted to produce the stable intermediate C(OH)2* rather than CO*, which proceeds the further hydrogenation to form HC(OH)2*, H2COH*, H3COH*, respectively, and followed by H3COH* desorption to CH3OH. Another formation pathway of CH3OH was proposed by Jiang et al. [242], who claimed the formation of CH3OH would be from the HCOO* pathway as the dominating reaction channel. Based on the DFT calculations, they found the initial hydrogenation of CO2 on open Zr sites in UiO-66 likely proceeds via the formation of the HCOO* intermediate because HCOO* formation is kinetically more favorable than COOH* (ΔG HCOO* vs. ΔG COOH* = 1.61 vs. 2.36 eV). The formed HCOO* intermediate will undergo hydrogenation steps of HCOO* → HCOOH* → H2CO* → H3CO* → H3COH* sequentially, and generate the final CH3OH product. It should be noted that the formed HCOOH* intermediate could also be desorbed from the catalyst surface to produce another liquid C1 product, HCOOH. A typical example is single atoms of palladium supported on g-C3N4 (Pd/g-C3N4) function as CO2RR photocatalyst carried out by Du and coworkers [239]. In this study, Gibbs free energy results show that the initial step of CO2* reduction is the formation of HCOO*, and the HCOO* to HCO* process has an energy barrier of 1.43 eV, as exhibited in Fig. 12(f). The formation of HCOOH follows the first two steps of the CH3OH pathway, after which HCOOH* is desorbed directly from Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst. The barrier of RDS in this pathway is 0.66 eV, which is lower than the barrier of HCOO* to HCO* process (1.43 eV) and the rate-determining barrier (1.46 eV) for the formation of CH3OH. These results suggest that HCOOH is the preferred product of CO2RR over Pd/g-C3N4 catalyst. In addition to these C1 products mentioned above, as exhibited in Fig. 12(a), C2+ products (e.g., CH2CH2, CH3CH3, CH3CHO, CH3CH2OH, etc.) could also be produced from photocatalytic CO2RR, and some of which have been recently reported with experimental and theoretical investigations [243–246]. The most challenging and key step in obtaining highly selective C2+ products is to initiate complex C−C coupling. During photocatalytic CO2 reduction, different C1 intermediates need to form tight bonds with different positive centers to establish sufficient coverage for further photoreduction or C−C coupling [247]. For instance, Guo and coworkers reported the efficient conversion of CO2 to CH3CH2OH using atomically dispersed indium and copper anchored on polymeric C3N4 as photocatalyst, and revealed that C−C bond was formed by the direct coupling of CO* to form *COCO based on DFT calculations [246]. Peter et al. [240] found that the hydrogenation of CHO* (Fig. 12(g)), followed by OC*-CHOH* coupling was the more suitable pathway for C−C coupling over CuGaS2@CuO photocatalyst, which can further hydrogenate to form the COHCHOH* intermediate or undergo dehydration to form CHCO*. These investigations further demonstrate that the key step in obtaining C2+ products from CO2RR is to stabilize the associated C1 intermediates and ensure that they participate in C–C coupling reactions. 4.5 Nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) NRR based on photocatalysis under mild conditions is regarded as a promising alternative to produce NH3 [248,249]. The photocatalytic NRR mainly follows that the N2 combines with photogenerated electrons and protons to form NH3 through a series of reduction steps, usually involving dissociative mechanism and associative mechanism (Fig. 13(a) ). The dissociation mechanism is similar to the classical Haber-Bosch process, where the N≡N triple bond is directly broken down into two nitrogen atoms, followed by the hydrogenation of a single nitrogen atom to form NH3. In the associative mechanism, the N2 molecules proceed continuously protonated to weaken and break the N−N interactions, which is regarded as the dominant mechanism for photocatalytic NRR to NH3 [250]. As exhibited in Fig. 13(a), the associative pathway can be divided into three possible reaction channels, that is, distal, alternating, and enzymatic pathways [251]. The different reaction pathways result in distinct requirements of catalysts, and the investigations based on DFT calculations can reveal the catalytic mechanisms and provide insights into the origin of catalytic activity during photocatalytic NRR studies. Several high-efficiency NRR photocatalysts have recently been reported with excellent NH3 conversion performance along distal pathways. For instance, Meng et al. [252] designed a defective-induced Pt modified BiOBr photocatalyst, Pt1/BiOBr-VO, presenting a high NRR activity. DFT calculations showed that the NRR preferred to be hydrogenated via alternative pathways (“end-on” configuration), with the N2 fixation route of N2* → NNH* → NHNH* → NHNH2* → NH2NH2* → NH2* + NH3* → NH2* → NH3* → NH3, as shown in Fig. 13(b). Highly active NRR catalysts should favor the generation of NNH* because the central intermediate in NRR is generally considered to be the process of hydrogenation of N2 molecules after adsorption to generate NNH*, which is considered to be the RDS in the entire N2 fixation process [253]. The calculated reaction potential of N2* hydrogenation on Pt1/ BiOB-VO is 0.71 eV, which is much lower than that of pure BiOBr (1.90 eV) and BiOB-VO (1.86 eV). On the Pt1/ BiOB-VO surface, the reaction energy required for the subsequent hydrogenation of NNH* to NHNH* is 0.69 eV, followed by the energy decline path of spontaneous hydrogenation and the energy of the subsequent hydrogenation process of NHNH*. The combined experimental and DFT studies demonstrated that oxygen vacancies and Pt facilitate the chemisorption and activation of N2 on the catalyst surface and supply sufficient H* for facilitating the hydrogenation of N2 and the formation of NH3. There is also an alternate mechanism (enzymatic mechanism) with the “side-on” mode, which is very similar to the alternating one. Dai et al. [254] rationally designed a metal-free single atom photocatalyst, single boron (B) atom supported on holey g-C3N4 (B@g-C3N4) using DFT calculations, which presented high NRR activity and selectivity. The results show that NRR tends to occur through the enzyme pathway, with an overpotential of 0.15 V and an activation barrier of 0.61 eV, which is lower than most metal-based NRR catalysts. This excellent NRR catalytic activity is derived from the “σ donation-π* back-donation” process, which plays a crucial role in the capture and activation of N2. Besides, another photocatalyst Penta-B2C with B as the active site has also been shown to be effective in promoting NRR by the enzymatic mechanism with an onset potential as low as 0.23 V [255]. Thus, these as-designed photocatalysts containing boron, B@g-C3N4 and Penta-B2C, would be appropriate candidates for further photocatalytic N2 fixation research. In a recent study, Xiong and coworkers [256] reported iron-doped TiO2 (Fe-TiO2) toward photocatalytic fixation of N2 to NH3 under ambient atmosphere and achieved efficient and selective photocatalytic performance. DFT calculations demonstrate that N2 adsorption takes an end-on configuration, and the adsorption sites in Fe-TiO2 and TiO2 are the Fe sites and Ti atoms near the oxygen vacancies, respectively. Moreover, N2 molecules at the Ti site tend to be hydrogenated in the binding alternate pathway for N2 reduction, as shown in Fig. 13(c), while for Fe-TiO2 catalyst, the subsequent hydrogenation of NNH* becomes easier with the gradual decrease of Gibbs free energy in the distal binding pathway. The change of nitrogen hydrogenation from the association alternating pathway to the association remote pathway may be due to the regulation of the local electron structure of oxygen vacancy by iron doping, which can adjust the local electron density of adsorbed N≡N and reduce the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step. Yin et al. [257] revealed that an applied external electric field would dramatically reduce the energy barrier for the activation of the N–N bond to form a NNH* intermediate from 2.65 to 0.95 eV over the 2D-layered Cs3Bi2Br9-CdS vdW junction. Additionally, the RDS during the conversion from N2 to NH3 via the same distal pathway is reduced from 2.65 to 1.68 eV in the presence of an external electric field, demonstrating Cs3Bi2Br9-CdS vdW heterojunction can theoretically be applied as a competitive photocatalyst for NRR. Overall, it was emphasized that DFT investigations are vital tools to uncover the photocatalytic NRR mechanism, which also helps in the development of NRR photocatalysts. 4.6 Other reactions In addition to the reduction of nitrogen to produce NH3, it can also be obtained by using NO3 − as a precursor, which is called nitrate reduction reaction (NO3 −RR) with eight-electron transfer, and the reaction mechanism of this reaction has also been studied extensively. For instance, Dong et al. [258] reported a NO3 − to NH3 photosynthesis route catalyzed by subnanometric barium oxide clusters loaded on TiO2 nanosheets (BaONCs-TNS), which exhibited a high ammonia photosynthesis rate with nearly 100% selectivity. The activation and reduction of NO3 − on the catalyst surface were revealed by DFT calculations, in which the ΔG were obtained to verify the effect of subnanometric BaONCs construction on the reaction energy and pathways. As shown in Fig. 14(a) , the results show that the ΔG rate required for *NOH → *NHOH (−1.63 eV) reduction is lower than that required for *NOH → *N (+2.31 eV) reduction. This means the *N generation is prevented, and N2 production is not an optional process on BaONCs-TNS. Moreover, facile NO3 − dissociation (*NO3 → *NO2) can be accomplished on BaONCs-TNS with an observable decrease in energy compared to that of pristine TNS, thus resulting in a highly selective eight-electron reduction of NO3 − for NH4 + photosynthesis. Similar theoretical investigations for NO3 −RR were also reported to insight into the mechanism for the design of improved photocatalysts [259,260]. Among the conversion reactions containing nitrogen, the oxidation of nitric oxide (NO) has received extensive attention in photocatalysis based on theoretical investigations as well. Zhang and colleagues [261] demonstrated that the selectivity of photocatalyzed NO oxidation for nitrates can be achieved by 99% on defect-engineered BiOCl (BiOCl-OV) under visible-light irradiation. The DFT calculation shows that O2 can be adsorbed to the surface of BiOCl-OV (001) by end-connected or side-connected bridge to form ∙O2 −. When NO is near the terminal ∙O2 −, it is oxidized to peroxynitrite (OONO−), releasing 1.32 eV of energy (pathway I), and then the O–O bond in the peroxynitrite breaks, releasing gaseous NO2 with a barrier of 0.49 eV. In another pathway (pathway II), side-junction ∙O2 − can directly oxidize NO to monodentate nitrates without any barrier, extracting a proton from adjacent hydroxyl groups or adsorbed water to form HNO3* with an energy release of about 1.64 eV. These results suggest that complete NO oxidation mediated by ∙O2 − side bridging precedes partial NO oxidation mediated by the end, which is confirmed by experimental studies. There are many photocatalysts such as TiO2 bearing oxygen vacancies and sulfur-doped C3N5 were used to catalytic NO oxidation, similar to defect-engineered BiOCl [265,266]. Selective organic transformations induced by photocatalysis have attracted more attention [267,268]. In a recent study, Wang et al. [262] reported that the dehydrogenative coupling of methanol into ethylene glycol (EG) can be achieved under visible-light over CdS photocatalyst. DFT studies show that the C−H bond breakage in methanol preferentially occurs on the CdS surface compared to O−H bond, because the formation energy of ∙CH2OH is about 0.5 eV lower than that of CH3O∙, as exhibited in Fig. 14(c). The formed ∙CH2OH intermediate has a very small adsorption energy of −0.2 eV on CdS, so it can easily desorpti-on from the CdS surface and perform thermodynamic downhill coupling to generate EG. For TiO2, the OH group of CH3OH has a moderate deprotonation energy and is more likely to form HCHO through the two-step route of proton transfer from CH3O– to CH3O∙ and then electron transfer. From another perspective, even if the strong adsorption of ∙CH2OH on TiO2 (adsorption energy −1.3 eV) is generated, the intermediate product will remain on the surface and then be continuously oxidized to form products such as HCHO. These results suggest that weak adsorption of ∙CH2OH on the catalyst surface plays a key role in the formation of EG. Cheng et al. [263] reported on surface-controlled photocatalysis of TiO2 for selective valorization of furfurals and vanillin and found that the reaction can be switched from hydrogenation of the aldehyde group to C–C coupling by manipulating exposed facets. It can be seen from Fig. 14(d) that the hydrogenation energy of (e− + H+) attacking carbonyl O atom to form ∙C−OH intermediate (I→II) is more favorable (0.61 eV) than that of (e− + H+) attacking carbonyl C atom (I→IV) (0.54 eV) on the VO-free anatase {101} surface. In contrast, on the surface of Vo-rich anatase {101}, the formation of CH−O∙ (I→IV) is exothermic, and the formation of ∙C−OH (I→II) is endothermic, so furfural tends to be produced by a two-step hydrogenation mechanism. These results agree with the experimental observations. Another transformations, conversing CH4 to other carbon-containing valuable chemicals with both high activity and selectivity, are also desired. At present, many studies based on dft have been used in the structure design, performance evaluation and mechanism simulation of CH4 conversion photocatalysts. For instance, Ye et al. [264] designed a hybrid catalyst of Au nanoparticle (NP) loaded ZnO/TiO2, presenting an efficient and selective photooxidation of methane catalyzed by dioxygen in a flow reactor to produce ethane. As displayed in Fig. 14(e), the CH4 is activated by ZnO to form adsorbed *CH3 and *H species, and then the *CH3 transfers from ZnO to Au, which could either couple with *O to form *OCH3 or directly desorb into the gas phase. DFT calculations show that Au, as a unique co-catalyst, can promote the desorption of CH3 to form ∙CH3 free radicals, which is a key step in the coupling of ∙CH3 free radicals to form C2H6, and prevent the competitive oxidation of CH4 to *OCH3, which is easily oxidized to CO2, and ultimately improve the formation of C2H6. The overoxidation of CH4 was inhibited. This is consistent with the difference in product selectivity over Au and Pt as cocatalysts observed in the experiment. 5 Perspectives and outlooks As described above, DFT calculations have been broadly employed to provide significant insights into photocatalysis, and tremendous progress has been achieved in recent decades. Fig. 15 summarizes the general applications of DFT investigations in photocatalysis, and several case studies are discussed in detail in the above sections. The DFT investigations have contributed significantly to disclosing the intrinsic electronic structure properties of photocatalyst materials and energy properties of photocatalytic reactions, which are essential for confirming the surface active sites in the reactions and providing effective guidance for the development of new target catalysts based on the acquired knowledge. Although DFT computation is playing an increasingly important role in the field of photocatalysis, its practical application still faces various challenges. It appears that the following are the main issues that need to be addressed: (1) Computational efficiency, cost, and accuracy. Computational prediction of the photocatalytic reaction products is difficult because all possible reaction pathways have to be studied, although theoretical insights can provide important clues and often achieve good consistency with the experimental observations. Moreover, all the photocatalytic reactions occur on the surface of catalyst, and the intrinsic structural properties of the surface layer of the catalyst are different from those in the bulk. Hence, how to choose the appropriate thickness of the model catalyst to simulate the surface structure of the real catalyst is very important. The choice of this model, and of course the choice of function and calculation method, not only affects the accuracy of the calculation results, but also determines the computational efficiency and cost, since the computational cost increases with the third power of the system size when performing DFT calculations using standard algorithms. Therefore, finding the right methodological compromise between computational effort (efficiency and cost) and desired accuracy, while still being as close as possible to “the right answer for the right reason”, is worth emphasizing. (2) Effect of electron excitation. It is worth noting that, at present, the DFT usually describes the ground state. Although it is often used to estimate the band gap and even the potential energy surface of an excited state, strictly speaking, these values have no physical basis. Furthermore, the surfaces of photocatalysts are dynamic, frequently undergoing change as the reaction proceeds. This means that theoretical simulations would require dynamic rather than static crystal models. Time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) has been used to study plasmons and other excitations in nanomaterials due to its ability to give insight into dynamic processes related to excited states [269,270]._ENREF_248 Nevertheless, the challenges in modeling complex nanocatalysts include describing photoexcited states in conjunction with excited state chemistry to explain the entire material system. (3) Complexity of the catalytic environment. In practice, the photocatalytic process takes place in a complicated reaction environment, in which the photocatalysts are surrounded by a reaction solution under light irradiation, while the DFT calculations are usually performed in a vacuum. This could result in differences between experimental and theoretical results. In addition, the composition of the reaction solution, such as the solvent effect, pH value, illumination intensity, etc., also makes a significant impact on the catalytic performance. Actually, it is rather difficult to take these complex cases into account simultaneously during the DFT calculations. Therefore, how to choose the appropriate parameters for the calculation system is crucial to obtain reasonable results and qualitative explanations. (4) New computational techniques or strategies. At present, due to the continuous improvement of DFT calculation methods, the development of algorithms also helps to improve the computational efficiency. Machine learning techniques are increasingly used to supplement experiments when studying complex chemical systems, an emerging strategy that is combined with high-throughput DFT calculations to obtain accurate and efficient computational results. This burgeoning strategy has begun to get widespread attention and application, and certain achievements have been reported [271–273], which shines a light on accelerating materials discovery, optimizing catalyst design, and advancing our understanding of complex processes such as photocatalysis. For instance, Zhang et al. [274] proposed an automated high-throughput workflow to efficiently screen 2D MA2Z4 (M = transition metal, e.g., Mo, W; A = C, Si, and Ge; Z = N, P, and As) photocatalytic OER catalysts, and anticipated that β-HfSi2N4 and β-ZrSi2N4 would be excellent catalysts for photocatalytic OER among the 648 candidates owing to their small exciton binding energy and fast carrier migration. Moreover, by harnessing the complementary strengths of DFT calculations and artificial intelligence (AI) techniques, researchers can unlock new opportunities for materials discovery, predictive modeling, reaction mechanism elucidation, and data-driven design in the field of photocatalysis [275]. This interdisciplinary synergy holds great promise for accelerating innovation, optimizing catalyst performance, and addressing key challenges in sustainable energy conversion and environmental remediation. In summary, there has been a significant growth in DFT calculation-based photocatalysis investigations, which has proven useful in catalyst design as well as in clarifying and confirming experimental mechanisms. Despite there are new challenges in the field of computational photocatalysis, the development of multi-scale models and machine learning methods based on DFT will bring bright prospects for the practical applications of DFT for photocatalysis. (1999) and Ph.D. (2004) and then worked as a faculty member at Nankai University. He began to pursue his postdoctoral research at the University of Pierre & Marie Curie in 2007. His research focuses on development of novel photocatalytic materials with wide visible light utilization and construction of efficient artificial photosynthesis systems.

coredata.dc:description: The conversion of solar energy to chemical energies by virtue of semiconductor photocatalysis has shown great significance in sustaining future energy demands, and have a deep understanding of the relationship between photocatalyst and photocatalytic activity is essential. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are becoming increasingly important for revealing the intrinsic electronic structure properties of materials and energy properties of reactions, which has been greatly developed with the development of computational methods. In this review, the applications of DFT calculations in photocatalysis are summarized and exemplified by various representative investigations in the up-to-date reports. To specify, we show how to collect, analyse and utilize the informations on photocatalysts and photocatalytic reactions with the help of the DFT calculations, such as electronic structures, surface catalytic sites, catalytic activities, possible reaction mechanisms, etc. Our discussion is intended to provide an overview on applications of the current theoretical calculations in the field of photocatalysis for a better understanding of the composition-structure-function relationships, and also to guide future experiments and computations toward the understanding and development of novel solar-energy-conversion catalysts.
